Dear Dr Wong,

Re:	Cathleen REEDMAN	DoB:  20/01/1971
	                      
I saw Cathleen in my clinic for follow up today.
She has tolerated the changes to her heart failure medications well and denied any postural symptoms.
Her repeat blood test showed slight elevation of her previous abnormal LFTs, but she reassured me that it was previously similarly abnormal in the past.

Her background is significant for dilated cardiomyopathy originally diagnosed in 2009, prosthetic aortic valve replacement in 2012 for severe aortic stenosis due to bicuspid aortic valve, left retinal vein occlusion in 2019, and persistent abnormal LFTs.
Cathleen is a non-smoker and non-drinker.

Her current medications include Warfarin, Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Entresto 97/103mg BD, Ivabradine 7.5mg BD, Spironolactone 50mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily, Frusemide 40mg daily, Pregabalin 50mg daily, Citalopram 20mg daily, Estradiol 1mg nocte, and Progesterone 100mg daily.
She has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 90bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
Today, I have added Empagliflozin 10mg daily for her heart failure.
I have warned Cathleen of an increased risk of recurrent UTIs and dehydration.
I will see her again in 2 months with another repeat blood test to keep an eye on her abnormal liver function tests.
Thank you for looking after Cathleen.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

Dear Dr Sia,

Re:	Youling LI	DoB:  01/10/1948
	                      
I saw Mrs Li in my clinic for follow up today.
Unfortunately, she took the Metoprolol regularly whilst wearing the Holter monitor, and therefore it showed only normal sinus rhythm with no significant tachyarrhythmias.
Mrs Li also has been experiencing occasional symptomatic hypotension with the home systolic BP down to approximately 90mmHg.
Mrs Li usually takes the entire Metoprolol tablet once daily in the morning.
Her background is significant for likely inappropriate sinus tachycardia, hypercholesterolemia, and hypothyroidism.
Her current medications include Metoprolol 50mg daily, Rosuvastatin 5mg daily, Amitriptyline 25mg daily, and Thyroxine alternate 50/75mcg daily.
She has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 80bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 110/70mmHg.
There was no postural drop today.
Today, I have changed the Metoprolol to Atenolol 25mg daily.
I have also asked Mrs Li to take all her medications at bedtime.
I will see her again in 2 weeks to check on her response.
Thank you for looking after Mrs Li.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

To: 	Dr Scott TESKE (019748CJ)
	Level 4, 15 Astor Terrace
	BRISBANE, QLD 4000
		
Dear Dr TESKE,

Re:	Alexandra GREEN	DoB:  25/03/1947
	                      
Thank you for your letter regarding Alexandra’s anticoagulation therapy in the context of surgery.

Her background is significant for paroxysmal AF, previous embolic CVA in 2023 with minimal residual neurological deficits, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (obesity phenotype), hypertension, and hypothyroidism.

Her current medications include Apixaban 5mg BD, Verapamil SR 240mg BD, Olmesartan 40mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Empagliflozin 25mg ½ tablet daily (private script for HFpEF), Frusemide 40mg daily, Levothyroxine 100mcg daily and Symbicort puffer.
She has no allergies.

Alexandra’s Apixaban should be withheld for 3 days prior to her surgery, and in view of her high risk of repeat thromboembolism/CVA from her paroxysmal AF, her anticoagulation should be bridged with Enoxaparin at 1mg/kg BD (i.e., 120mg BD since her last recorded weight with me was 116.6kg).
The Enoxaparin should be withheld on the morning of her surgery, and the Apixaban restarted as soon as possible after surgery once you are happy with haemostasis.
In addition, Alexandra’s Empagliflozin should also be withheld for 3 days prior to her surgery to avoid the risk of euglycaemic ketoacidosis when fasting.
Thank you for looking after Alexandra.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

	Smart Clinics Annerley

Dear Dr Venkyataraman,

Re:	Kang San OOI	DoB:  12/09/1948
	                      
Thank you for referring Mr Ooi to my clinic for review of his cardiac medications.
He is a 75-year-old gentleman with a background of type 2 diabetes, non-obstructive coronary atherosclerosis on previous CT coronary angiogram, and hypercholesterolemia.
He is a non-smoker and non-drinker.
Mr Ooi was originally diagnosed with non-obstructive coronary atherosclerosis on both invasive coronary angiogram and CT coronary angiogram in Malaysia.
At that time, he had atypical chest pains and despite the non-obstructive disease, he was prescribed Trimetazidine for presumed angina.
Over the last couple of years, he denied any recurrence of previous chest pains despite taking the anti-anginal medication every second day.
Mr Ooi also asked about his sinus bradycardia today.
Although his nocturnal heart rate has been down to 42bpm on a Holter monitor, he denied any history of lightheadedness or syncope.
Mr Ooi is normally physically very active and denied any exertional symptoms.
His current medications include Trimetazidine, Rosuvastatin 10mg ½ tablet daily, Fenofibrate 145mg ½ tablet daily, and Metformin XR 500mg mane/1000mg nocte.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 50bpm regular, and his blood pressure was 120/60mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur.
His ECG today showed sinus bradycardia (ventricular rate 49bpm, PR 202ms, QRS 92ms, QTc 397ms).
Today, I have informed Mr Ooi and his family that we can stop his Trimetazidine as he does not experience any angina.
As for his sinus bradycardia, he also does not require any pacing support as he is completely asymptomatic.
I have organised for him to have an echocardiogram at the end of the year after he returns from Malaysia again.
Thank you for looking after Mr Ooi.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

	Albert St Cbd Medical Centre
	Level 3, 138 Albert St
	BRISBANE, QLD 4000 
		
Dear Dr Jao,

Re:	Lu HAN	DoB:  11/01/1958
	                      
Thank you for referring Mrs Han to my clinic for further assessment of chest pain.
She is a 65 year old lady with a background of hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia.
She is a non-smoker, non-drinker, and there is no family history of premature cardiovascular disease.
Mrs Han recently experiences chest tightness approximately 1 month ago.
The chest tightness does not radiate and can last for several hours in duration.
In addition, the chest tightness is not aggravated by physical exertion, but at times relieved with exercise.
She subsequently underwent an echocardiogram and exercise stress echocardiogram.
They reported a structurally normal heart, and no inducible ischaemia.
In terms of her hypertension, most of her home systolic BP readings have been >130mmHg.
As for her hypercholesterolaemia, the latest fasting LDL cholesterol was 4.5mmol/L.
Mrs Han does not take any regular medications and has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 70bpm regular and her blood pressure was 145/90mmHg.
Cardiovascular examination was normal.
ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm (PR 150ms, QRS 98ms, QTc 471ms).
Today, I have reassured Mrs Han that she is a low risk patient with non-cardiac chest pain.

In addition, the normal exercise stress echocardiogram indicates that the likelihood of underlying severe obstructive coronary artery disease is low, and her risk of an acute myocardial infarction is less than 1% in the next 1 year.
As for her cardiac risk factors, we discussed about the pros and cons of a cardiac CT.
Following our discussion, she has elected to proceed with treatment of both her hypertension and hypercholesterolaemia without the results of a cardiac CT.
Therefore, I have started her on Candesartan 4mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively.
I will see her again in January next year with a repeat fasting lipid profile.
Thank you for looking after Mrs Han.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

Dear Dr Wang,

Re:	Him Wee LIM	DoB:  21/08/1958
	                      
Thank you for referring Mr Lim to my clinic for further management of ischaemic heart disease.

He is a 65 year old gentleman with a background of coronary artery disease and previous PCI to mid LAD in 2014 in Malaysia, mildly dilated ascending aorta under observation, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, obesity, obstructive sleep apnoea on CPAP, fatty liver disease, and GORD.
He is an ex-smoker, and occasional social drinker.
Clinically, Mr Lim is asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view and denied any exertional chest pain or dyspnoea.
In terms of his cardiac risk factors, he informed me that his home systolic BP is usually approximately 130mmHg.
His latest fasting LDL cholesterol was 2.0mmol/L.

His current medications include Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Telmisartan 80mg daily, Amlodipine 10mg daily, Hydralazine 50mg daily, Moxonidine 400mcg daily, Rosuvastatin 40mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily, Fenofibrate 145mg daily, Frusemide 40mg daily, and Pantoprazole 40mg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 60bpm regular, and his blood pressure was 140/80mmHg.
Cardiovascular examination was normal.
ECG today showed sinus rhythm and RBBB (PR 198ms, QRS 164ms, QTc 446ms).

His latest echocardiogram in 2022 reported normal left ventricular size and systolic function, dilated right ventricle with normal function, no significant valvular abnormalities, and dilated aortic root.
Today, I have asked Mr Lim to check his home BP and to increase the Hydralazine to 50mg BD if it is consistently more than 130/80mmHg.
As Mr Lim will be leaving for Malaysia for 2 months on this weekend, I will see him again at the end of the year for an echocardiogram when he returns to Australia.
I will also start him on Evolocumab 420mg monthly S/C under the non-familial hypercholesterolaemia criteria at that time.
Thank you for looking after Mr Lim.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

	Runcorn Plaza Family Medical Practice

Dear Dr Akbar,

Re:	Robert MATTHEWS	DoB:  29/07/1950
	                      
Thank you for referring Robert to my clinic for further management of anticoagulation.
It has been more than 4 years since I last saw him at my ATSICHS outreach clinic at Woolloongabba.
He subsequently saw Dr Paul Watson at Greenslopes hospital for several years, and is currently no longer seeing a Cardiologist regularly.
Since I last saw him more than 4 years ago, he developed paroxysmal AF and was started on Rivaroxaban.
However, his Aspirin therapy was not stopped and he recently had a significant episode of epistaxis.
It has since resolved and not recurred again after stopping Aspirin 3 weeks ago.
He has been well and asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view in the last few months, and denied any angina or palpitations.
His background is significant for paroxysmal AF, ischaemic heart disease with previous PCI to OM1 and OM2 (DES), hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, type 2 diabetes with microalbuminuria, and gout.

His current medications include Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Metoprolol 50mg BD, Candesartan 32mg daily, Moxonidine 200mcg daily, Ezetimibe/Rosuvastatin 10/40mg daily, Metformin XR 1000mg daily, Empagliflozin 25mg ½ tablet daily, Semaglutide 1mg weekly S/C, Allopurinol 300mg daily, and Duodart 500/400mmcg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 80bpm regular and his blood pressure was 130/60mmHg.
His previous exercise stress echocardiogram in 2021 reported normal resting LV function.
Today, I have changed the Empagliflozin to Dapagliflozin 10mg daily under the chronic renal failure PBS criteria so that we can concurrently prescribe it with Semaglutide.
I have also informed Robert that he does not need to restart Aspirin therapy, and he should continue on Rivaroxaban monotherapy at this stage.
I will see him again in 1 year for follow up.
Thank you for looking after Robert.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

Dear Dr Yuan,

Re:	Katrina MITCHELL-FLEGO	DoB:  03/03/1969
	                      
Thank you for referring Katrina to my clinic for further assessment of palpitations and “dizziness”.
She is a 54-year-old lady with a background of bipolar disorder.
She occasionally smokes cigarettes and regularly consumes approximately 2 standard drinks daily.
Katrina has a long history of palpitations for the last 5 years.
Usually, she described it as a sensation of skipped/extra heart beats that are highly suggestive of ectopic beats.
It only lasts for several seconds in duration and occurs daily.
As for her “dizziness”, it is a sensation of movement despite standing/sitting still, and the symptoms are highly suggestive of mild vertigo.
In the last few months, the frequency of her palpitations and “dizziness” has increased following changes to her HRT treatment.
Her current medications include Estradiol/Norethisterone patches.
She has no allergies.
On examination today, her pulse rate was 70bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 110/70mmHg.
There was no postural drop today.
Cardiovascular examination was normal.
ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm (PR 134ms, QRS 86ms, QTc 409ms).
Today, I have organised a 24-hour Holter monitor to exclude any significant arrhythmias.
I have also organised an echocardiogram to exclude any structural heart disease.
I will Katrina again in 2 weeks for follow up.
Thank you for looking after Katrina.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

To: 	Dr Azadeh Abtahi (432359GK)
	Underwood Family Practice
	9/21 Kingston Road
	UNDERWOOD, QLD 4119 
		
Dear Dr Abtahi,

Re:	Ali GOHARFAR	DoB:  08/03/1977
	                      
Thank you for referring Ali to my clinic for further management of hypertension and assess the need for treatment.
He is a 46 year old gentleman with no other significant medical history.
He is a non-smoker, non-drinker, and denied any illicit drug use.
Ali does not have a family history of premature cardiovascular disease or hypertension.
Ali has a long history of hypertension.
However, it appears to be predominantly white coat hypertension and diastolic hypertension.
He recently had a 24hr ambulatory blood pressure that showed his systolic BP is usually normal, but the average diastolic BP is elevated.
In contrast, his clinic blood pressure readings usually shows that both his systolic and diastolic readings are elevated.
Not surprisingly, he developed symptomatic hypotension when prescribed antihypertensive medications.
Ali recently returned to Iran earlier this year and his echocardiogram at that reported a structurally normal heart with no left ventricular hypertrophy or left atrial dilatation.
Ali does not take any regular medications and has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 65bpm regular and his blood pressure was 150/90mmHg on both arms.
Cardiovascular examination was normal.
ECG today showed normal sinus rhythm (PR 144ms, QRS 106ms, QTc 416ms).
Today, I have informed Ali that difference in systolic BP on the 24hr ambulatory BP monitor and the clinic readings confirm that he has an element of white coat hypertension.
In addition, the 24hr ambulatory BP monitor also showed that he has isolated diastolic hypertension.
I have informed Ali that the evidence on the adverse cardiovascular effects of diastolic hypertension is conflicting.
However, treatment of isolated diastolic hypertension often results in symptomatic hypotension as the medications will also reduce the systolic BP.

Following our discussion, Ali has decided to continue lifestyle modifications to control his blood pressure, including regular cardio exercises, reduced dietary salt intake, and additional weight loss.
In the meantime, he will need to keep an eye on his home blood pressure regularly instead of relying on our clinic blood pressure readings.
I have not made a regular follow up appointment to see Ali at this stage, but please do not hesitate to refer him back again in the future if required.
Thank you for looking after Ali.

Kind Regards,

Associate Professor Arnold Ng

She is a 42-year-old lady whose other background history includes chronic fatigue syndrome and hypothyroidism.
She is a non-smoker, and non-drinker.
There is no family history of premature cardiovascular disease or sudden cardiac death.
Lauren complains of “palpitations” over the last 2 years.
She described the palpitations as a sensation of strong heart beats that is associated with exertional dyspnoea.
Her symptoms tend to occur during physical exertion.
She denies any history of syncope, orthopnea, or PND.
Her current medications include Naltrexone 0.3mg daily, Thyroxine 25mcg daily, and Valacyclovir 500mg daily.
She has no allergies but is intolerant to Aspirin (vomiting and diarrhoea).
On examination today, her pulse rate was 60bpm regular, and her blood pressure was 90/50mmHg.
Cardiovascular examination was normal.
There was no peripheral oedema.
On exercise stress echo today, she was able to walk for 11:00 min:s on the Bruce protocol and achieved 13.50 METS (93% maximum predicted heart rate).
The test was terminated due to target heart rate achieved and she was dyspnoeic starting from stage 2 of the Bruce protocol.
The resting ECG was normal and there were no ischaemic ECG changes or arrhythmias at peak stress.
The resting LV function was normal, and there were no significant valvular abnormalities.
There were also no inducible wall motion abnormalities at peak stress.
It was a normal exercise stress echo.
Today, I have reassured Lauren that she has a structurally normal heart on her resting echocardiogram images, and her stress echo did not show any inducible arrhythmias or ischaemia.
Therefore, there are no cardiac contraindications for her to start stimulants for her ADHD.
I have discharged Lauren from my clinic back under your care.
Thank you for looking after Lauren.

														Dear Dr Chan,





RE:	STANLEY R. ADNESS	DOB:	20/07/1950		UR:	354620

							





It was a pleasure to review Stanley in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today via phone consultation.
As you know he is a 72-year-old gentleman who has been getting atypical chest pain for a number of months.
He underwent a CTCA which reported eccentric mixed density plaque with negative remodelling in the proximal LAD where focal borderline high-grade stenosis could not be excluded.
He then had an exercise stress echocardiogram at the Logan Heart Centre where he could only walk for 2 ½ minutes (achieving 82% of his maximum predicted heart rate) due to dyspnoea.
He subsequently underwent a dobutamine stress echocardiogram here.
During that study, he had frequent ventricular ectopy and a run of monomorphic non-sustained VT while dobutamine was infusing at 30mic/kg/min.
He was asymptomatic and there were no other signs of inducible ischaemia.
This all occurs on a background of hypertension and being an ex-smoker.
His current medications are Aspirin 100mg, Rosuvastatin 10mg, Atenolol 50mg, Telmisartan 40mg and Nicorandil 5mg bd.
Stanley reports having a few episodes of chest pain over the last few weeks.
They have been reasonably mild and short lived.
He has used his GTN on occasion with some effect.
He continues to play golf without any major issues and the pain does not seem to be related to exertion at all.
I have recommended a coronary angiogram to exclude any severe proximal LAD disease, given the equivocal nature of Stanley’s ESE and DSE now.
Stanley is happy to proceed, and we will organise this test here in the near future.
I will review him in clinic with the results.

Yours sincerely, 



Electronically signed 12.01.23

Dear Dr Morison,





RE:	ADETOMIWA AGBOOLA	DOB:	11/06/1984	UR:	2113589

							





														Problems:

														Cardiomyopathy with hypertrophic phenotype.
Abnormal cardiac MRI with a ring like pattern in anterolateral segments (sub-epicardial localisation) and oedema in the septum on delayed enhancement.
Matched increased FDG uptake with normal perfusion on myocardial perfusion scan.
Mild increase in LV wall thickness with a reduced strain but preserved LV ejection fraction on echocardiogram.
Family history of sudden cardiac death in 29-year-old brother.
No evidence of cardiac arrhythmias on monitoring or stress echocardiogram.
Normal cardiac structure and no evidence of coronary artery disease on CT coronary angiogram.
No symptoms.
Arterial hypertension on treatment.
Elevated body mass index.

Medications:

														Candesartan 8mg daily, Amlodipine 5mg daily, unable to tolerate Beta blocker.
I saw Mr Agboola today.
He has been well and has no symptoms.
His case quite challenging.

It initially suggests the presence of familial arrhythmogenic left ventricular cardiomyopathy with classical sub-epicardial, left ventricular delay enhancement on MRI and family history of sudden cardiac death.

Interestingly though we found some oedema in the anteroseptum and abnormal FDG uptake on cardiac PET which would be more consistent with inflammatory cardiomyopathy, either sarcoidosis or myocarditis.
I had a discussion with Mr Agboola regarding the next step.
I think the chances of making a tissue diagnosis are low, especially in view of the sub-epicardial localisation of the abnormalities on the left ventricle.
However, there is a chance that the acute oedema does represent inflammation hence biopsy of his right ventricle septum could be of value.
I have left him with information regarding the procedure.
I will also refer him to my colleague at RBWH, Professor John Atherton who is experienced in the genetic cardiac disease.

RE:	ADETOMIWA AGBOOLA	DOB:	11/06/1984	UR:	2113589

														

														I feel that we should seriously consider him for a prophylactic defibrillator as his risks are elevated and continue to be significant throughout his life.
I will leave that decision to my colleague Dr Paul Gould.
I have made no changes to his medications.
I will be seeing him again in the 6 months or probably sooner if he decides to proceed to the biopsy.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 17.01.23

														Dr Dariusz Korczyk

														Consultant Cardiologist

Dear Arun,





														RE:	MAJA AGERBEEK		DOB:	13/10/1936		UR:	1158935

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Borderline severe aortic stenosis.

Mean gradient 39mmHg

														Patient does not report symptoms at present.
Normal left ventricular function.
No documented cardiovascular risk factors.

Other Diagnoses:

														Chronic back pain / sciatica, requiring opioid medication.
Osteoporosis and previous crush fractures.
Mild asthma (allergen induced).
Benign breast mass 2020 (prior breast implants).

Medications:

														Norspan patch, Vitamin D 1 daily, Pregabalin 75mg BD, Panadol Osteo 2 BD, Premarin daily and Prolia.
Cease Meloxicam.
I reviewed Maja in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic at the PA Hospital today with her daughter present.
Maja is  very spritely 86-year-old lady who continues to work as a School Cleaner in Shailer Park.
She is somewhat hampered by chronic back pain which I understand is largely due to degenerative disc disease, but she strongly denies any exertional dyspnoea today.
She has never suffered chest pain nor syncope.
Maja does not have any cardiovascular risk factors.
She has hay fever / asthma for which she uses Salbutamol on occasion, and chronic pain on the above-mentioned medications.
She had a hysterectomy in 1989.
I note she is still on Premarin.
Maja lives alone.
She is of Dutch Indonesian heritage.
She has never smoked and does not drink alcohol.
Her blood pressure today was 130/58mmHg and her pulse rate was 66bpm in sinus rhythm.
She had dual heart sounds with a late peaking ejection systolic murmur, but a fairly brisk carotid pulse.
Her chest was clear, and she had minor pedal oedema.
She had reasonable distal pulses.
Her ECG shows sinus rhythm with a borderline 1st degree AV block and frequent  PVCs.
Her echocardiogram today shows preserved biventricular function, and moderate to severe aortic stenosis with a mean gradient of 39mmHg.

Assessment and Plan:

														Maja has borderline severe aortic stenosis but denies any symptoms of repeated questioning today.
We discussed the nature history of aortic stenosis, weighed against the benefits and risks of intervention with TAVR.
She is still yet  to have her CT TAVR, but we will pursue this in the coming weeks.
I think it most appropriate that we review Maja again in 3 months, to carefully watch for the emergence of symptoms.
This is certainly her preference as well.
She understands that chest pain or syncope should prompt emergency presentation to hospital.
Lastly, given her cardiac disease and age, I have advised her to avoid NSAIDs and she will cease her Meloxicam.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sonny,





														RE:	SAIYED ALI		DOB:	26/05/1972		UR:	8095706

																					

														

														

														Mr Ali came along with his wife for review.

He had myocardial infarction in October 2021 and on angiogram he had co-dominant circulation with 70% stenosis of mid LAD and moderate to severe diffuse disease of distal LAD with a culprit tandem lesion of 80% stenosis, chronic total occlusion of mid RCA, and his left circumflex artery had mild calcification with 80% stenosis of the 1st left posterol-lateral artery.
He was found to have iron deficiency anaemia and reported 1 month history of PR bleeding.

He was managed medically with plan to undergo outpatient urgent colonoscopy, quit smoking and if he were to have intractable angina or ischaemia on medical therapy, to revisit revascularization either CABG or PCI.
This recommendation was by consensus of the Heart Team comprising of cardiologists and cardiothoracic surgeons.

On colonoscopy, he was found to have a large pT3N0 rectosigmoid adenocarcinoma and underwent a laparoscopic assisted large anterior resection of the rectum with end-to-end anastomosis and discharged in December.
He is stable from cardiac point of view and reports no ischemic symptoms and is tolerating his medications well.
He exercises on treadmill at home.
There has been no anaemia or further PR bleed.
He has resumed working as a forklift driver.
His bloods from 4cyte pathology July 2022 show Hb of 144, MCV 91.2, Chem20 unremarkable and ferritin at 332 with T sat at 21%.
He takes aspirin 100mg daily, ticagrelor 90mg bd, metoprolol 50mg bd, tamipril 5mg nocte, rosuvastatin 40mg nocte, pantoprazole 40mg mane, GTN prn which he has not required to use since discharge.
His blood pressure is well controlled.
Today, it is 118/70mmHg and he is euvolemic.
He has not had a repeat LDL level which sat at 3.6mmol/L at the time of myocardial infarction.
I have given him a pathology slip to have repeat lipid profile.
You could add Ezetimibe if his LDL is not on target i.e.
less than1.4mmol/L.
He has quit smoking.
I have shown him his angiogram pictures and discussed extensively the role of secondary prevention therapies a well as maintaining his positive lifestyle changes.
In order to monitor his symptoms, we will continue to review him annually for now.
We are more than happy to see him sooner if he reports any angina.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Alison,





RE:	GEORGIA ALLEN		DOB:	21/03/1998		UR:	2234463

							

														

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Georgia today 18.01.2023.
She is a 24-year-old disability support worker who has had palpitations, shortness of breath and dizziness for many years.
She gets daily palpitations which are consistent with ventricular ectopy.
They have been associated with syncope in the past.
She has not had a syncopal episode in 10 years, but these were mostly with exercise.
She did get sudden onset of palpitations at rapid rates in association with exercise.
Her ECG confirms normal sinus right with right ventricular outflow tract ectopy with a transition at V5 and a positive R-wave in lead I, likely from ventricular outflow tract septal region.
She had a normal euthyroid function test, normal urea and electrolytes.
She has had an echocardiogram performed on 26.09.2022, with normal left ventricular function, normal right ventricular function, normal valvular function.
She has had a 24-hour Holter monitor with 30% burden of ventricular ectopy which is large, and her symptoms were consistent with ventricular ectopy.

She had no recorded non-sustained VT.  

														

														She is a non-smoker and imbibes alcohol rarely and takes caffeine infrequently.
She has no family history of sudden cardiac death and an ECG today confirmed normal sinus rhythm with right ventricular outflow tract ectopy.
She has no other past medical history, and she is medicated currently on Norimin the oral contraceptive.
She has a diagnosis of right ventricular outflow tract ectopy which is symptomatic.
The sudden onset of tachycardia is unclear but may be related to her association with ectopy.
The 24-hour Holter monitor did not record any other arrhythmia than ventricular ectopy.
I have commenced her on Metoprolol 25mg orally BD, acknowledging that she does not suffer from asthma.

She is for a repeat 24-hour Holter monitor on Metoprolol and for an exercise stress test off Metoprolol for 2 days prior and a transthoracic echocardiogram, a signal average ECG and I have also organised a cardiac MRI to rule out any evidence of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

RE:	GEORGIA ALLEN		DOB:	21/03/1998		UR:	2234463

														

														I have organised to review her in 3 to 4 months in my Private Practice Clinic, at which stage we will assess her need for antiarrhythmic drug therapy and consideration for ablation of the right ventricular outflow tract ectopy.
I would be happy to see her earlier should the need arise.
Many thanks again for your kind referral.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	TIMOTHY ALLEN		DOB:	17/04/1937	UR:	1068370

														Diagnoses:

														CABG 2000.
EP study in 2013 apposed syncope.

Positive for VT 

														ICD implanted by Dr G Kaye in 2013.
Battery at end of life.
No requirement for generator change (no high voltage therapies from the device in the last 10 years and high risk of infection).
Alzheimer’s dementia.
I did a telehealth conference with Timothy from Kingaroy Hospital today.
He is an 85-year-old gentleman who was brought into the PA Hospital for a generator change as his ICD battery is close to end of life.
He had a skin infection, which he is known to have had for a long period of time and due to intercurrent infection, the ICD generator was not changed.
I had reviewed him for the first time, and I noticed that he has Alzheimer’s dementia as well.
We also noticed that the ICD was implanted after a positive EP study in 2013.
This was done for a history of syncope.
He has never had any high voltage therapies in the last 10 years since he has had his ICD and is not requiring any pacemaker function from the ICD as well.
Based on this and the wishes from Timothy and his wife, Beverley, they have both opted for no generator change.
I think this is very reasonable and is my recommendation as well.

Not only that he has not required either the pacemaker function or the ICD function from his defibrillator, but also this may probably do more harm than benefit by causing infection, which is he really prone to due to his current skin infections.
He will continue to have regular follow up with yourself and the cardiology team at the Kingaroy Outreach Clinic.
I have discharged him from regular follow up but would be happy to see him if there are any arrhythmic issues in the future.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	TRUDY ALLEN		DOB:	14/08/1978		UR:	218429

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Secondary prevention AICD in situ.
VF arrest 2018.
ICD MicroPort CRM 1540 platinum DR, atrial lead Soren Tilda R53, RV lead Boston Scientific 0692 reliance for front SG.
Significant burns from device and MRI requiring skin grafts despite appropriate precautions taken.
Multiple sclerosis with recurrent flares requiring further MRI brain.

Background:

														Non-dilated cardiomyopathy.
Recent EF 47%.
Cardiac MRI – No infiltration of fibrosis.

Followed up at Ipswich Hospital

														Hypertension.
Scheuermann’s disease.
Hiatus hernia.
Asthma.

Current Medications:

														Dapagliflozin 10mg, Ivabradine 7.5mg BD, Fingolimod 0.5mg daily, Atorvastatin 20mg, Candesartan 32mg, Frusemide 40mg, Metoprolol XL 190mg daily, Moxonidine 200mcg BD, Pramipexole 0.125mg nocte PRN, Spiractin 75mg daily, Pregabalin 25mg BD, Paracetamol PRN, Desvenlafaxine 100mg daily, Esomeprazole 40mg daily.
We are writing you in the hope that you may assist with the management of his lady.
Trudy has a MicroPort device with a Boston Scientific RV lead and a Sorin right atrial lead.
She has significant multiple sclerosis for which she sees Dr Beer her Neurologist at Mater Hospital.
She is required to have MRIs as part of the investigation and management of her multiple sclerosis.
Given her different manufacturers, there was an attempt at an MRI with appropriate precautions, however, despite this, she had significant skin burns requiring grafts at the RBWH, after the MRI.
She is required to have further MRI’s and we therefore saw her in the clinic to try to come up with a plan to facilitate this.
Her main background is a non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy which she has regular follow up at Ipswich Hospital for.
She has a follow up with the Ipswich Team in March of this year.
On examination today, her blood pressure was 130/80mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and she was euvolaemic.
In discussion with Dr Hill, we were hoping that you might be able to assist with device extraction.

Our thought is that it would be reasonable to remove both her right atrial lead which is a Sorin and her generator and replace these with a Boston Scientific who is the manufacturer of her right ventricular lead.
Given the device has been in since 2018, we would require your assistance with this matter.
She otherwise has follow up at Ipswich Hospital for her heart failure and follow up at the Mater Hospital for her multiple sclerosis.
Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Knowles,





RE:	BRIAN AMOS		DOB:	23/02/1947		UR:	761681

							



														

														It was a pleasure to meet Brian and his wife in the clinic today.
I have taken over his care from Dr Paul Garrahy.
I note that Paul looked after him for many years and he has had several stents over the years.
He had check coronary angiograms in 2018 and 2020 that were triggered by presentations with an increase in his anginal symptoms.
The latter of which was also stimulated by a myocardial perfusion scan done by Dr Pashar.
The most recent check cath in 2020 showed a widely patent left circumflex, a right coronary artery with minimal irregularities, a 50% mid LAD lesion and a 70% small diagonal lesion.
He is currently on good medical therapy, including Aspirin, Ramipril.
Atorvastatin, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg daily, Nicorandil 10mg BD, as well as Insulin, Trajentamet, Pariet, Actonel, Lyrica and puffers.
He is back to getting angina 1 to 2 times a week.
He seems more concerned about breathlessness on exertion, although I suspect this is more likely due to obesity and deconditioning.
He can only walk about 50 metres before becoming breathless.
He is using his GTN a couple of times a week and also uses relaxation.
Examination today revealed a blood pressure of 90/60mmHg and a heart rate of 60bpm and regular.
Venous pressure was not elevated,  heart sounds were dual, the chest was clear and there was mild to moderate peripheral oedema.
Paul had had a detailed discussion with Brian about weight loss.
He had asked him to lose about 30 kilograms.
He still weighs about the same that he did 3 years when Paul spoke to him.
I explained to Brian and his wife that we cannot use angiograms as a routine way of tracking coronary artery disease.
I understand that exercise stress echocardiogram are unlikely to give a good results and the myocardial perfusion scan has  previously been falsely positive.
I think it would be reasonable to get him a dobutamine stress echocardiogram.
I would only change to an invasive strategy if he had an abnormality on a dobutamine stress echocardiogram or he developed an acute coronary syndrome.

RE:	BRIAN AMOS		DOB:	23/02/1947		UR:	761681

														

														I have explained to him that even with an invasive strategy and possible stenting, the breathlessness is unlikely to change.
I will see him again after the dobutamine stress echocardiogram.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Novic,





														RE:	PETER PAUL ANTONINI		DOB:	07/06/1964	UR:	939495

																					

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review Peter in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you  know he is a 58-year-old gentleman.

He has a history of:

														Inferior STEMI Jun 2022, primary PCI to the RCA.
Initial LVEF 30-35% improved to about 40% on recent echocardiogram.
Initial reduced RV function now normalised on recent echocardiogram.
Type 1 diabetes with poor control.
Dyslipidaemia.
Smoker.
Bilateral BKA.
Peter’s current medications include Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Atorvastatin 80mg, Metoprolol XL 75.5mg, Pantoprazole and Insulin.
Peter has not experienced any further significant chest pain.
I was concerned at our last review about some episodes of loss of consciousness.

He underwent a Holter monitor where then leads came off after 11 hours, but during the recording period he did report one episode of dizziness and another of chest pain which were associated with isolated PVC’s.
He had two cycles of 2:1 AV block at 6.50pm of which he was asymptomatic, but I do not think we should increase his Beta blocker any further due to this.
Peter’s description of his episodes of loss of consciousness are a little bit inconsistent today.
He had previously reported that they usually occurred whilst standing.
He now states they usually occur when he sits down after a period of exertion.
He said they have been happening for eight years  He reports no warning symptoms and that he is out for 5 or 10 minutes but does not think he has fallen asleep.
He does feel a bit dazed when he comes to.
He has never injured himself during these episodes.
Peter also reports a constant left temporal headache today.
Today, Peter’s blood pressure was 123/80mmHg and he was euvolaemic.
I have asked Peter to have some bloods with a lipid profile and I will also organise a CT head, given his report of headaches.
I will review him in June, but please feel free to contact me in the meantime with any issues or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

No history of syncope and no family history of sudden cardiac death or cardiomyopathy.
Patient not on any QT prolonged pharmacotherapy.
Patient and patient’s pharmacy provided with list of long QT medications to avoid on 11/8/2016.
Normal cardiac structure and function with satisfactory valvular function for age on transthoracic echocardiogram at PA Hospital on 21.2.17.
Previous small pericardial effusion.
Follow up transthoracic echocardiogram on 5 March 2018 demonstrates trivial pericardial effusion only with no other significant abnormalities.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

Significant white coat/anxiety component.

														Anxiety.
Previous rosacea.
Previous iron deficiency anaemia.
Cervical spondylosis.
Vulvar atrophy.

Medications:  

														Perindopril 10mg daily, Diltiazem 180mg once daily.
I had the pleasure of seeing Nancy in Dr Camuglia’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
We have been monitoring her for a while.
She remains asymptomatic with no palpitations, no syncope or blackouts and no other concerning symptoms.
She does have trouble with her blood pressure lately, especially when she is anxious, such as today.

Her ECG today shows sinus rhythm with a QTc of 459ms.

Dear Dr Gilbert,





														RE:	IRENE ARMSTRONG	DOB:	22/02/1952	UR:	1124900

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Irene, a lovely 70-year-old female, I had the pleasure of reviewing on behalf of Dr W Ahmad today in the Cardiology Arrhythmia Clinic.

Her medical issues include:

														Atrial arrhythmias.
AF (persistent) / atrial flutter / SVT.
Reduced frequency on Flecainide and Verapamil.
On the wait list for catheter ablation.
CTI ablation in 2015.
Evidence of sinus node dysfunction / pauses requiring a right sided DDD PPM implantation on 31.10.2022.
Congenital heart disease.
Partial anomalous venous return to right middle lobe and both upper lobes to lateral SVC plus ASD.
Pulmonary vein baffle to LA plus ASD closure in 2015.

Cardiac MRI performed in June 2022, showed a moderately dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function, no significant residual atrial septal defect, intact baffle, superior branch of the left pulmonary vein appeared to be draining into the SVC, normal LV systolic function and no evidence of an infiltrative process.
Hypertension.
TIA in 2014.
Left breast DCIS managed with a wide local excision and completed adjuvant radiotherapy.
Her current medications include Flecainide 100mg twice daily, Verapamil 240mg once daily and Eliquis 5mg twice daily.
Since Irene’s pacemaker, she was having episodes of palpitations and dizziness.
One that lasted 24 hours and resulted in her presenting to the PA Hospital on New Years Eve.
These symptoms spontaneously resolved whilst in hospital and she was discharged with no medication changes.
In the New Year, thankfully she has had no further symptoms and remains well apart from some fatigue.
She had her device interrogated last week, that is of satisfactory function and no arrhythmias were detected.
On examination today, her blood pressure was 160/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, and her chest was clear on auscultation.
She had no peripheral oedema.
Our plan is to increase her Flecainide to 125mg twice a day.
Given that she was hypertensive, I have also taken the liberty of commence her on Candesartan 4mg and advised her to see you in 2 weeks to check up on the progress.
Please feel free to titrate her antihypertensive medication as you see appropriate.
As mentioned early, Irene remains on the weight list for a catheter ablation.
However, we have organised a 6-month clinic review for her to see how she is progressing.
Thank you for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Dear Dr Ari,





RE:	DAVID ASH		DOB:	28/02/1958		UR:	8102387

							



														

														

														

														It was a pleasure to review David in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 68-year-old gentleman who was admitted here in March 2022 with an aborted lateral STEMI.
Coronary angiogram revealed very aneurysmal and ectatic coronary arteries.
No other significant aneurysmal disease was identified on CTA of his head, neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis.
The findings would be consistent with a previous vasculitis such as Kawasaki’s.
This also occurred in the context of poorly controlled hypertension.
His LVEF at the time was about 45%.
I note David was readmitted to hospital in October with an episode of syncope after standing for several hours in the church band.
His antihypertensives were reduced at this stage.
Apart from that he has been very well.
He is back to all of his usual activities and is quite active around the home and in his church.
He gets no chest pain.
Formal exercise is limited by some right knee discomfort.
I  understand he is quite keen to have a knee replacement soon due to the limitations it is placing on his mobility and his fitness.
He is seeing Dr Cooke at the Mater regarding this.
David’s current medications are Rivaroxaban 15mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Perindopril 4mg, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Amlodipine 10mg, Atorvastatin 80mg and Pantoprazole.
Today, David’s blood pressure was 155/85mmHg.
He assures me that it is usually normal when it is measured in the GP clinic and the last reading was 120/70mmHg.
In summary, David is stable from a cardiac point of view.
We will organise an up-to-date echocardiogram and I will review him via phone with the results.

In regard to his risks for undergoing orthopaedic surgery, he is at increased risk of cardiac ischaemia with any interruption to his anticoagulants due to the aneurysmal nature of his coronary arteries.
However, this is an ongoing risk and I do not think delaying any surgery would reduce it.
Therefore, his cardiac status is optimised at this time.

RE:	DAVID ASH		DOB:	28/02/1958		UR:	8102387

														

														I will write to you further with the result of his echocardiogram.

If he were to undergo any surgery, I would suggest interrupting his anticoagulants for the minimum amount of time possible and performing the operation on a single antiplatelet (clopidogrel or aspirin) if possible.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Cheng,

														

														

														RE:	DEREK ASPINALL		DOB:	30/09/1972		UR:	601210

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:

														# IHD with multiple previous medically managed NSTEMIs - Known to Dr Wahi at  PAH
   - medically managed due to weight - unable to have Angio on any table > 250kg-

														        -Last NSTEMI 27/11/22 -peak TnT 309
    -Not able to exclude PE as unsuitable for CT- commenced on apixaban 5mg BD purely bases on clinical suspicion no DVT on LL dopplers
TTE 29/11/22:
   - Dilated left ventricle with moderately reduced systolic function.

LVEF ~40% by

														     visual estimation.

- Dilated right ventricle with preserved systolic function on limited views 

														     obtained.
Mild mitral regurgitation.

# Lipodermatosclerosis with recurrent cellulitis (and episode of septic shock Oct

														   2021 requiring ICU admission complicated by trop leak  and significant deconditioning
   - further admission Nov 2021 with cellulitis)
# Class III Obesity
   - BMI 85.5
   - Peak weight 283.15kg May 2021
   - Currently 277kg (Nov 22)
   - Known to complex obesity clinic PAH
# T2DM
   - on metformin 1g daily, insulin (basal bolus Toujeo + NovoRapid), Semaglutide
# OSA on CPAP - compliant
# GORD
# R ankle ORIF post MVA then subsequent metalwork removal
# Hypothyroidism
# Severe Anxiety/PTSD


														Current Medications:

														Nicorandil 10mg BD, Dapagliflozin 10mg mane, Apixaban 5mg BD, Bisoprolol 5mg mane, Clopidogrel 75mg mane, Atorvastatin 80mg nocte, Frusemide 40mg mane, Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg 2 tablets mane, Levothyroxine 50mcg mane, Magnesium 2 tablets twice a day, Metformin XR 1g nocte, Nizatidine 300mg 1 tablet nocte, Pantoprazole 40mg mane, Ramipril 2.5mg nocte, Thiamine 100mg mane, Insulin, Semaglutide, Ozempic once a week, GTN spray, Salbutamol, Panadol.
I had the pleasure of talking to Derek via telephone from the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
This was his phone review, since discharge from hospital in December 2022, when he was admitted with troponin positive chest pain.
Derek is a complex, multi-morbid, severely obese gentleman who is not suitable for any investigations.
This is purely due to his inability to lay on any investigation beds.
His body weight is 264 kilograms and unfortunately with this body weight we cannot take him to the Cath Lab or CT scanners.

Due to the recurrent hospital presentations of chest pain and trop leak, he was treated as possible pathologies of pulmonary embolism +/- acute coronary event and was discharged home on Apixaban 5mg BD and Clopidogrel.
There have been no complications/bleeding with this therapy so far.
In terms of his progression, his chest pain symptoms were quite well controlled until last week, when he started to get chest pain on and off again.
He feels that he is getting his body weight up trending and accumulating fluid again.
He is currently on 40mg Frusemide mane and 80mg in the afternoon and feels that his legs are swelling up again.
He checks his blood pressure by himself and reports a good reading at 120 to 130 systolic at home.

It is quite possible that given his LVEF of 40% with his other complex cardiac issues, he could have mild decompensation of his heart failure, which is contributing to his anginal symptoms and also making him short of breath.
Keeping that in mind, I have increased his frusemide dosing to 80 mg BD.
If BP allows then we could consider adding thiazide like diuretics in future.
He is also on possibly maximal antianginal medications at the given blood pressure range.
At this stage, we plan to see him in 3 months with an echocardiogram prior to the clinic review.
Please feel free to continue your care and contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Irannezhad,





														RE:	JOSEPH ASSAD		DOB:	17/12/1949		UR:	2408988

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Joseph Assad today in the Cardiology Research Clinic.
This is a routine 3 monthly clinic appointment as part of his enrolled in the HELIOS-B clinic trial which is targeting his amyloidosis diagnosis.
Joseph tells me that he has been feeling very well since his last review.
He continues to play tennis on a daily basis without significant dyspnoea.
He has no symptoms of decompensated  heart failure or any chest discomfort.
In fact, he has no complaints overall.
In particular, he denies any orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea or changes to his night vision.
The only issue outstanding is that you have noticed his PSA has been gradually increasing, for which he had a PET scan yesterday to investigate this further.
I will leave the ongoing investigation and management of this in your capable hands.
On examination today, Joseph appeared well and in good spirits.
His blood pressure was 132/83mmHg and his heart rate was 64bpm and regular.
His heart sounds were dual with an ejection systolic murmur in the aortic region radiating to the carotid and a pan systolic murmur in the mitral region.
His jugular venous pressure was not elevated.
His chest on auscultation was normal.
On examination of his abdomen, I noticed a rectus sheath hernia, and I reassured Joseph today that this is largely cosmetic in nature.
However, should he experience any severe abdominal discomfort, I have advised him to seek medical attention promptly.
There was no hepatosplenomegaly, and his kidneys were normal.
There was no lymphadenopathy on examination today.
There were no significant changes to his skin, except for a small coffee burn in the epigastric region, which is healing nicely.
In summary, Joseph has been very well while on the trial medication.
We will arrange to continue administering the trial medication as per the protocol and he we will see him at his next scheduled appointment in approximately 3 months.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Assad.

Yours sincerely,

														RE:	PETA MICHELLE ATTRILL		DOB:	19/05/1973	UR:	289388

																					

														

														

														I had the pleasure of following up Peta in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Peta has been stable recently.
She had a dobutamine stress echocardiogram last year, which did not reveal any evidence of inducible ischaemia.
Her left ventricular function was normal.
She did have an admission to hospital last year due to an infection in her left arm.
She has been stable from that perspective for the past few months.
Peta tells me that she has been taking Xarelto for recurrent clots.
She tells me that she is frequently somewhat tachycardia despite taking Atenolol 100mg daily.
On examination today, her heart rate was 90bpm and blood pressure 155/90mmHg.
Her heart sounds were dual with no murmur, chest was clear, JVP was not elevated and there was no peripheral oedema.
It was noted that after Peta stood up, her heart rate did exceed over 110bpm.
Peta is overall stable from the cardiac perspective for now.
She has been tachycardic in the past, especially when associated an infection.
Now she does however appear to have some element tachycardia associated with standing (potentially POTS).
Peta tells me that she does eat breakfast and is well hydrated during the day.
I think given her complex medical issues and that this tachycardia otherwise does not trouble too much symptomatic, I am happy to leave things alone for now.
Provided she remains stable, I am happy not to review her here on a routine basis.
Please feel free to refer her back in the future, if I may be of further assistance.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Rotkirch,





														RE:	MAUREEN BACCIN		DOB:	9/12/1952		UR:	2129151

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your referral of Mrs Baccin.
She has a very complex past medical history with a lot of symptoms.
The basic story is that she has had breast cancer in the past, she has had chemotherapy, and some sort of immune modulation.
She tells me that she is known to have gastroesophageal disease.
She has daily chest pain, which is atypical for angina in that it occurs at rest.
She had a stress echocardiogram performed at the Logan Heart Centre where she developed chest pain but there were no ECG changes, and no wall motion abnormalities.
Clinically, she is obese which explains her breathlessness.
Her chest is clear, there is no elevation of the JVP, no oedema and her blood pressure is 113/79mmHg.
Her pulse is 76bpm.
Her 12 Lead ECG is sinus rhythm and normal.
Mrs Baccin is at low risk given the stress echocardiogram result, but she will continue to present with chest pain, until we provide a more definitive diagnosis.
She is very reluctant to start medication, but I have advised her that we do diagnose coronary disease, she will need to take Aspirin, Statin and Beta blocker as first line therapy.
She has agreed to a Beta blocker, and I have prescribed Bisoprolol 2.5mg in the morning.
I have ordered a CT coronary angiogram.
We will review her after that.
Unless she has critical and prognostic important coronary disease, I think we would be aiming to manage her medically.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Hong,





														RE:	DEBRA BAILEY		DOB:	16/04/1958		UR:	792499

																					

														

														

														Medical Issues:

														Paroxysmal SVT.
Episode of long RP tachycardia in 2018 which could indicate a possible non-sustained atrial tachycardia.
Admitted to hospital and observed and spontaneously resolved.
Reviewed at GCH and booked for EP study .
Moved to Brisbane and saw Dr Gould in October 2021 and was put on PA Hospital EP study wait list.
I reviewed Debra Bailey in Dr Gould's EP clinic today.
She is on waiting list for EP study at the PA but has already had this performed on at the GCUH in November 2021.
This EP study was negative.
There was decremental central conduction with no evidence of accessory pathway.
No jump or echo beats seen and no inducible arrhythmia, even on 10mcg/min on Isoprenaline.

There were frequent single PACs on Isoprenaline, mostly from CS 5,6, earliest P wave morphology was positive in V1, negative II – III, and morphology was not always identical, and her symptoms were not replicated.
Overall, this was a negative EP study.
It was recommended that Debra went on a beta blocker or a calcium channel blocker, but she did not want to be on these medications, and she maintains this position.
She takes Lexapro and works as an ICU porter.
She went through a right total elective knee replacement about 3 months ago without any tachyarrhythmia or cardiac issues.
ECG today is completely normal.

She tells me that she has never had palpitations, what she usually experiences is the physical inability to inspire or take a breath sometimes to an extent where she has to make herself gag to be able to breath.
This is an unusual symptom.
She reports she generally feels unwell when she lays down at night-time to go to sleep, but once she falls asleep, she does not wake up due to orthopnea.
Certainly, there are no features of decompensated heart failure on examination today.
I cannot find an echocardiogram on the system, and she mentions that she does not ever recall having an echocardiogram which is unusual.
She has had a recent negative EP study and does not want to trial medications and her symptom of the physical inability to breath in is rather unusual.
I do no think this is explained by any of her PVCs or PACs.
However, she does need an echocardiogram to rule out any structural or functional abnormalities of her heart.
If her echocardiogram is normal, we will discharge her from our clinic and remove her from the EP waiting list.
I wonder if she needs ENT / respiratory review as well for her symptoms.
She will have an echocardiogram in the next 2 months and review her chart and make some further plans.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Lahanas,





RE:	LILLIAN JUNE BAIN		DOB:	22/06/1932		UR:	303703

							









														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Transcatheter aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis.
TAVR at PA Hospital on 15.10.2021 with Abbott Navitor 27mm bioprosthesis.
Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
Elevated right heart pressures on echocardiogram.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Dyslipidaemia.
Hypertension.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic kidney disease with previous ANCA vasculitis.

Under follow up with renal service at the PA Hospital

														Previous thyroidectomy.
Osteoarthritis with reduced mobility.
Macular degeneration with reduced visual acuity.
Meningioma.

Medications:

														Apixaban 2.5mg twice daily, Omeprazole 20mg daily, Atenolol 25mg daily Dothiepin 75mg at night, Atorvastatin 10mg daily.
I reviewed Lillian Bain today.
Things are stable.
She has had no angina, no prolonged or pathological palpitations and no syncope.
Lillian does have to pay close attention to maintaining adequate food and fluid intake, including salt intake, given her significant diastolic dysfunction and small left ventricular cavity.
Her follow up echocardiogram was satisfactory with a well seated, well function TAVR bioprosthesis with good haemodynamics.

RE:	LILLIAN JUNE BAIN		DOB:	22/06/1932		UR:	303703

														

														

														Plan and Recommendations to LMO:

														Continue DOAC at appropriate dose for age, rate and renal function as per product information (current Apixaban 2.5mg twice daily).
Antibiotic prophylaxis for any invasive procedures, including dental procedures as a lifelong recommendation.
Repeat cardiology review in 2 years.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Fordyce,





RE:	GARY BAJGAR		DOB:	11/02/1956		UR:	664919

							



														Gary returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He has been well.
He describes class I NYHA symptoms, and denies any orthopnoea, PND, dizziness or light headedness.

Medications

														Immunotherapy 2nd weekly for melanoma treatment, Spironolactone 25mg mane, Hydralazine 25mg BD, Bisoprolol 10mg mane, Valsartan 80mg nocte, Atorvastatin 40mg nocte, Allopurinol 600mg mane, Panadol PRN, Tramadol PRN.
His medications are now maximally titrated for heart failure therapy.
Gary complained of sore nipples last week which lasted for about 4 to 5 days, and it has now resolved.
I have asked him to keep an eye on this.

I have informed him should the nipple pain or swelling return and/or worsens then he should discuss with you the possibility of changing the Spironolactone to Eplerenone which does not have this side effect.
On examination his blood pressure was 100/50mmHg sitting and 110/70mmHg standing, heart rate 68bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have made no changes to his medications as he has reached maximum tolerated doses of heart failure medications.
He will have follow up with the cardiology team here at the Princess Alexandra Hospital as planned.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Podagiel,

														

														

														RE:	PETER BALENS		DOB:	05/09/1950		UR:	387216

																					

														

														

														Thank you for referring Mr Balens, I had the pleasure of reviewing him in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
Mr Balens is a 72-year-old man who has been referred to us for aortic stenosis.
I not that his echocardiogram in October 2022, was reported as moderately severe aortic stenosis, however, the aortic valve velocity was 4.06m/s with a mean gradient of 40mmHg and DSI of 0.22.
Mild to moderate aortic stenosis was also noted.
He had normal left ventricular size and systolic function.
Mr Balens does not appear to have any exertional symptoms or chest discomfort or shortness of breath.
He has not had any syncopal or presyncopal episodes.
He tells me that he does his gardening and 2 weeks ago was able to mow his lawn without significant difficulties.
He tells me that he remains physically active.
He tells me that his 6 push ups and 5 chin ups a day.
He tells me that some of his mobility is limited by his lumbar spine with disc issues in L5-S1 resulting is sciatica.
He is semi-retired by still delivers spare parts and also drives for meals on wheels intermittently.
He also helps with other people’s gardens.
He lives in his own house and has a friend living in it at the moment.
He is divorced.
He does not drink alcohol and does not smoke.
Mr Balens tells me that he has 4 children with 3 of them living in Brisbane at the moment.
On examination today, his heart rate was 164bpm, and his blood pressure was 148/80mmHg.
Heart sounds were dual with no murmur, chest was clear, JVP was not elevated and there is no peripheral oedema.
His ECG today shows sinus rhythm.
I note in his last echocardiogram report, although the indices point to severe aortic stenosis, it was only reported as showing moderately severe aortic stenosis.
In any case, he appears to be asymptomatic at this stage.
To further monitor Mr Balens, I will organise for him to have an echocardiogram in about April of this year and I look forward to reviewing him again after that.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Cho,





RE:	CUONG THANG BANH	DOB:	04/12/1948	UR:	1014878

							



														Thank you for your recent phone call.
Mr Banh’s atrioventricular conduction had deteriorated (evident on ECG 2nd July 2022) and there was concern about his upcoming right arm AV fistula revision surgery.
I recommended addition of Theophylline SR at 100mg twice a day, with food, with Pantoprazole daily.
Mr Banh came back for review by my invitation, with a Vietnamese interpreter.
He negotiated the fistula surgery apparently without problems and haemodialysis has been established satisfactorily using that fistula now.
He awaits removal of the right sided Permacath.
He does not have any cardiac symptoms and he feels significantly better since the institution of Theophylline.
Today his blood pressure was 155/65mmHg sitting.
His pulse was 75bpm with long cycles of AV Wenckebach.
He has 200mg Theophylline tablets which are scoured so that they can be cut in half.
They must not be crushed.
Please let me know when the Permacath has been removed.
I have discussed with Mr Banh the nature of permanent pacemaker implantation today.
I believe that a leadless pacemaker with atrial sensing may be the best options for him.
I will mail him more information about the pacemaker procedure, which he can discuss with his daughter, Ann, who is probably his best English-speaking contact.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Hayman,





RE:	JULIA BARLOW		DOB:	14/12/1972		UR:	016860

								

	



Issues:

	Myotonic dystrophy.
Permanent pacemaker in situ (dual chamber St Jude pacemaker).
Implanted by Dr G Kaye in 2014 for AV block.
RV lead nose most likely due to insulation break.
Satisfactory pacemaker function and threshold testing on review today.
New diagnosis heart failure reduced ejection fraction.
Awaiting further work up but likely secondary to myotonic dystrophy.
EF 40 to 45% with global hypokinesis on TTE  24.01.2023.

Current Medications:

Zoloft, Atorvastatin, Ramipril 1.25mg introduced today, Bicor 1.25mg introduced today, Spironolactone 12.5mg introduced today.
I had the pleasure of seeing Julia in Dr Ahmad’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
We have been watching her for a while, mainly in terms of her permanent pacemaker with a likely insulation break in her RV lead, but stable parameters, therefore just for monitoring.
When I saw her last year in this same clinic, I thought we would update her echocardiogram, given her background of myotonic dystrophy and the fact that it had been a couple of years.
Unfortunately, her echocardiogram now shows her EF has dropped to 40 to 45%, where it had previously been normal.
I suspect this is just in keeping with the known consequences of myotonic dystrophy.
We will however arrange some additional tests to confirm there is no alternate cause.
Symptomatically, she does not report any syncope, palpitations or any other concerns.
She is NYHA class I and has no breathlessness, no orthopnoea or no other concerning symptoms.
Her blood pressure was 125/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual, chest was clear, and she was euvolaemic.

The plan is as follows:

	I have given her a script for Ramipril 1.25mg.
I have given her a script for Spironolactone 12.5mg.
I have given her a script for Bisoprolol 1.25mg.
The introduction of the Bisoprolol may cause us to start to see some problems the pacemaker, given the RV lead issues.
If she ever has any syncope, she needs to call an ambulance and present to hospital.
If her breathing worsens or she is dizzy, she also needs to present to hospital.
We will arrange for her to see us in a few months, and I note she also has a pacemaker check in a couple of weeks.
For further investigation of the reduced ejection fraction, she will have a cardiac MRI and CTCA scheduled.
We will refer her to the Heart Failure Nurse Practitioner for  up titration of her medications.
It will be preferable to increase both the Ramipril and Spironolactone to max tolerated doses before touching the Bisoprolol.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Ranasinghe,

														

														

														RE:	LEE BARRY		DOB:	10/06/1959		UR:	2218708

																					

														

														

														I saw Barry in my clinic for follow up today.
He has been well and asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view over the last few months.
His main complaint today is intermittent claudication in his left leg, likely due to his peripheral vascular disease.
He is awaiting further review by the vascular surgeons.
Barry also underwent an exercise stress echocardiogram recently.
It was a submaximal test (82% maximum predicted) due to Beta blocker usage.
Despite that, there was no evidence of inducible ischaemia, and he was asymptomatic at peak stress.

His background is significant for underlying atherosclerosis with an abnormal CT calcium score in 2022 (59th percentile), peripheral vascular disease, with previous bilateral lower limb stenting, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia.
Barry has a positive family history of premature cardiovascular disease, and he is an active smoker.
His current medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Ramipril  2.5mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, and Tamsulosin 400mcg daily.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 70bpm regular, and his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
There was mild bilateral pitting oedema in the lower 1/3 of the shins.
Today, I have increased the Ramipril  to 5mg daily to aim for a target BP <130/80mmHg.
I have also given Barry a pathology request form to check his fasting lipid profile.
If the LDL cholesterol is >1.8mmol/L, can you please start him on Ezetimibe 10mg daily?
I will see him again in approximately 6 months, with another repeat fasting lipid profile.
Thank you for looking after Barry.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Constantinescu,





RE:	SIMON BARTLETT		DOB:	24/09/1964		UR:	485503

							



Simon attended the heart failure titration clinic today for consideration of up titration of his heart failure medications.
As you know this gentleman has a past history of atrial fibrillation with a difficult to control heart rate.
He has heart failure with reduced ejection fraction secondary to the tachycardia.
Echocardiogram in October 2022 showed EF 20-25%.
He is current smoker and has COPD.
He smokes both cigarettes and marijuana.
He has OSA which is untreated.
He has bipolar effective disorder and borderline personality disorder, type II diabetes mellitus, CKD and dyslipidaemia.

Medications

Carvedilol 62.5mg BD, Cholecalciferol 50mcg mane, Fluoxetine 40mg mane, Frusemide 20mg mane, Magnesium 1g BD, Nicotine Patch, Olanzapine 30mg nocte, Perindopril 2.5mg nocte, Pravastatin 80mg nocte, Rivaroxaban 15mg mane, Resonium A 15g Mon/Thu, Thiamine 300mg mane, Valproate 1g BD.
Simon lives alone and has a previous heavy alcohol intake.
However, currently he is only having occasional alcohol.
He told me that he is eating well.
He has occasional diarrhoea, and the last episode was two days ago where he took Lomotil with good result.
He told me that he takes his medications about 90% of the time.
He smokes 15 to 30 cigarettes per day and has 6 to 10 cones of marijuana per day.
He describes class III NYHA symptoms with his exercise tolerance about 40 metres.
He denies any orthopnoea or PND.
He is experiencing ongoing dizziness at times.
He denies any chest pain.
On examination his blood pressure was 88/50mmHg sitting and 80/50mmHg standing, he was asymptomatic with this.
His heart rate was 88bpm and irregular via peripheral pulse.
There was no evidence of oedema.
The main concern for Simon today was intermittent nocturnal urinary incontinence.
He has had a number of micro urine tests to check for infection.
The most recent one being on the 28th December here at the hospital which was negative.
I discussed this with our Urology Incontinence CNC today.

She would be happy to see him however she would like some further investigation prior to determine if there a possibility of urinary retention with overflow which could be secondary from his antipsychotic medications.

RE:	SIMON BARTLETT		DOB:	24/09/1964		UR:	485503







I wonder if you would be so kind as to organise an ultrasound KUB and refer Simon directly to her.
Her details are Colleen Marsh, fax number 3176 2542.
This is rather than through the Hub.
She is aware of this gentleman and will keep an eye out for the referral.
In the meantime, in an attempt to improve his blood pressure, I have withheld the Frusemide until review with the General Medicine team on the 17th January 2023.
I have made no other changes to his heart failure medications as he is likely at maximum tolerated doses due to ongoing low blood pressure.
I note his renal function test from 28th December showed a slight improvement with his Creat 194 and eGFR of 32.
His Hb is low at 102 and his K+ 4.7.
I have made a further appointment for him in this clinic in 6 weeks however I am not sure that I will be able to move any further with his heart failure medications.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Latona,





														RE:	BELINDA FAY BASS		DOB:	10/11/1988		UR:	1122433

																					

														

														

														Issues:

														Mitral valve prolapse / mitral annular disjunction.
Mild to moderate MR.

Mild mitral annular disjunction,

														Non-sustained VT on Holter monitor.
4 beat non-sustained VT on EST.

Current Medications:

														Atenolol 25mg daily.
I had the pleasure of seeing Belinda for follow up alongside Dr Ahmad today.
She is tolerating her 25mg of Atenolol fairly well and does report the occasional brief palpitations.
There has not been any syncope or dizziness and she does not suffer too much in the way of side effects.
We reviewed the exercise stress test and the Holter monitor that you kindly assisted with.
There was still a 4 beat non-sustained VT after the EST and more concerningly, it does appear to be short coupled as on some prior investigations.
Dr Ahmad had an extensive discussion with her regarding the pros and cons of doing an EP study and PVC ablation.

We explained that whilst the natural history and management of this disorder is still somewhat unclear, we do know that there is an increased risk of sudden cardiac death and given the nature of the ectopy proceeding to an EP study and PVC ablation would be a reasonable recommendation.
We explained to her that there is up to a 2% risk of major complications including major bleeding, urgent surgery, stroke, heart attack and death.
She is happy to proceed with this and we arranged for this to be booked in.
She will need to stop her Atenolol a few days prior to the procedure.

She will have follow up after this proceed and otherwise we have asked her to present to your practice if there is any concerning change in symptoms and if she does have a syncopal episode she is to present to the emergency department.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Matthew,

														

														

														RE:	WILLIAM G. BASSETT	DOB:	07/07/1962	UR:	1128402

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of William, a 60-year-old gentleman I had the pleasure of reviewing on behalf of Dr Ng today for management of his mild dilated cardiomyopathy, secondary to previous Doxorubicin therapy.
His other medical issues include, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Barrett’s oesophagus, fatty liver disease, obesity and significant anxiety and depression.

His current medications include Aspirin 100mg, Mirtazapine 30mg, Valproate 1.5g mane – 2g nocte, Ezetimibe / Simvastatin 10/80mg nocte, Duloxetine 120mg, Creon, Bisoprolol 5mg once daily (reduced by Dr Ng from 10mg in July due to issues with bradycardia and hypotension), Ivabradine 5mg BD, Entresto 24/26mg BD and as required Diazepam.
On review today, I am pleased to report that William has been very stable from a heart failure perspective.
He denies any postural symptoms or concerns of dizziness or syncope.
Unfortunately, his shortness of breath on exertion persists,  however, he attributes this largely to his poor fitness.
He does not partake in any exercise, has a suboptimal diet and drinks at least 2 beers every night.
On examination today, his blood pressure 122/70mmHg without a postural drop.
He had central adiposity and his last weight on our system from 2021 was 127 kilograms.
His chest was clear on auscultation and his heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
He had evidence of pitting oedema.
He had an echocardiogram in September last year which I am pleased to report had only mildly reduced LVEF of 45 to 50% with no significant valvular abnormalities.
Thank you for sending William’ blood results with him today, where I note his haemoglobin  was 149 with transferrin saturations of 29% and an LDL of 1.4.
Our impression today is that William has very stable mild LV dysfunction.

Our recommendations are:

														Weight loss, cut down alcohol intake and consider a dietetics review.
Review in 9 to 12 months with a repeat echocardiogram.
I have recommended to William that there is room to up titrate his Entresto to 49/51mg nocte.
The patient will think about this, and I have provided him with a prescription should he wish to increase this.
If he develops any issues with hypotension, then this can go back to his current dose.
Thank you for  your ongoing care for William and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,
