														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														 Aortic stenosis.
Moderate to severe aortic stenosis with normal left ventricular ejection fraction.
Coronary artery disease.
Peripheral vascular disease with previous right lower limb revascularisation procedure and asymptomatic left internal carotid artery disease.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Ex-smoker.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic kidney disease.
Bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees.
Renal lesion under surveillance.
Reduced mobility requiring 4-wheel frame for mobilisation.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Amlodipine 2.5mg daily, Rosuvastatin 20mg daily, Metoprolol 50mg twice daily, Perindopril 5mg daily.
I reviewed Jocelyn Battcock today in the Heart Valve Clinic at the PA Hospital.
She attended the appointment alone.
I have asked her to bring one of her children to her next review with us.
Jocelyn has moderate to severe aortic stenosis on echocardiographic assessment.
Jocelyn also has a significant burden of peripheral vascular disease.
She has borderline acceptable left femoral access for a potential TAVR procedure in the future.
Jocelyn lives at home alone.
She is independent with personal activities of daily living.
She drives a care.
Her cognition is intact.
We discussed the natural history of the aortic valve disease including a 50% risk of heart failure or death within the next year or two without procedural intervention.

In relation to transcatheter aortic valve replacement we discussed the potential risks including a risk of 10% - 20% major complications that could include: stroke resulting in permanent disability, inability to walk or talk, blindness, death or permanent nursing home placement; major vascular or cardiac complications including dissection, rupture, the need for major reparative surgery, death or limb loss; kidney failure requiring permanent use of a dialysis machine; infection resulting in the need for major open heart surgery and or death.
We also discussed a 20 - 30% risk of requiring a permanent pacemaker as a result of the procedure.
The relevant written educational material outlining these issues was also provided (UQ Version 2021).
She has borderline acceptable left femoral artery access for a transcatheter aortic valve replacement procedure with a self-expanding prosthesis.
She also has fairly borderline axillary access and her carotid access would be somewhat fraught given her documented cerebral vascular disease.

Overall, I explained to Jocelyn that she is at higher-than-average risk, even for her age, for having a significant adverse event with a transcatheter aortic valve replacement procedure and in particular, this could be disabling stroke, resulting in permanent disability, nursing home placement or death.
Overall, Jocelyn and I reached the consensus that we should hold off any aortic valve intervention until she has critical disease given the attended risk in her specific scenario.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Repeat review in the heart valve clinic in 3 months with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram.

Provisionally may be suitable for a left transfemoral approach for transcatheter aortic valve replacement in the future, if and when aortic valve disease progresses into a situation where the risk benefit equation justifies procedural risk.
Jocelyn is aware to bring one of her children to her next appointment, so we can discuss the above listed issues in more detail with her family member.
Any interval changes in symptoms, in particular, increased shortness of breath, fainting or near fainting, or chest pain, Mrs Battcock is aware to call 000 and attend the hospital.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Arcibal,



RE:	MICHAEL BEAMISH		DOB:	12/09/1946		UR:	8067407

							

														Michael returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
Since I commenced him on the Spironolactone 12.5mg nocte, Michael noticed quite severe insomnia.
He had no symptoms of nocturia, he just couldn't sleep.
Therefore, Michael took it upon himself to change the Spironolactone to the morning which resolved these symptoms.
I understand that he saw you shortly after and you adjusted the dosing times of his Bisoprolol and Ramipril to assist in keeping his blood pressure level throughout the day.
Thank you for this.
Symptomatically Michael has been very well.
He has no PND, orthopnoea, chest pain or palpitations.
He does notice occasional postural dizziness on standing quickly.
He has been doing his blood pressure at home and these range between 110-120 systolic / 60’s diastolic.
Thank you for arranging a blood test with QML on the 12th January 2023.
These show a stable renal function with Na 138, K+ 4.4, urea 8.7, creat 103, and eGFR61.

Medications

														Rivaroxaban 20mg mane, Frusemide 80mg mane (reduced to 40mg mane), Bisoprolol 2.5mg lunch, Ramipril 2.5mg nocte, Digoxin 62.5mcg mane, Dutasteride 500mcg mane, Pantoprazole 40mg mane, Vitamin D mane, Vitamin B12 mane, Magmin 500mg 2 tabs a day, Breo Ellipta 1 puff mane, Ventolin prn, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane.
On examination his blood pressure was 100/60mmHg sitting and 100/70mmHg standing, heart rate 64bpm and irregular.
He had no peripheral oedema.
His lungs were clear.
Today Michael is euvolemic.
I have asked him to trail a reduction in the Frusemide from 80mg to 40mg mane.
I have instructed him to increase this back to 80mg if he should get any peripheral oedema, a weight gain of 1-2kg in 1-2 days or heart failure symptoms like increased shortness of breath.
I will call him in 2 weeks and if his blood pressure has improved with this small change, I will commence the gentle titration of the Ramipril.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Jeanette, a lovely 63-year-old female, I had the pleasure of reviewing on behalf of Dr W Ahmad today, alongside her husband.

Medical Issues:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Severe LAD stenosis treated with a drug eluting stent in August 2021.
Mild circumflex and RCA stenosis.
Preserved LV systolic function.
Nicotine dependence (current smoking 5 cigarettes a day).
Excessive alcohol intake (managed to cut down to 3 stubbies/day).
Hypertension.

Current homelessness (living with her father at a retirement village)

														

														Jeanette has been very stable since her last review with Dr Ahmad in September 2021.
She had 1 admission to the Ipswich Hospital with troponin negative chest pain after which she underwent an exercise stress test.
This was negative for any inducible ischaemia.
She denies any  heart failure symptoms and reports good compliance to her medications.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg, Perindopril 2mg, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Atorvastatin 80mg, Venlafaxine, Levothyroxine and as required Nitro lingual Spray.

On examination today, her blood pressure was 100/70mmHg, heart rate was regularly regular, and her heart sounds were dual with no murmurs.
She was euvolaemic on review today.
Her ECG showed sinus rhythm at 71bpm with old ischaemic changes consistent with her previous infarct.
Unfortunately, Jeanette has not had any blood tests given her recent social stresses and homelessness.
Our impression today is that Ms Beasley is stable from her ischaemic heart disease perspective, however, requires ongoing risk factor modification.
I had a lengthy chat with Jeanette about the importance of smoking cessation as well as reducing her alcohol intake.
I have reiterated that once her social situation is a little bit more stable, she needs to touch base with you have blood tests done including her lipid profile.
We are aiming for an LDL < 1.4 and if on her upcoming blood tests this is not the case, please add Ezetimibe 10mg to her current medication list.

Yours sincerely,

Dilated ascended aorta.
Bicuspid aortic valve.
Hypertension.

Intermittent smoking.

Dear Chris





														RE:	MARK BEGGS		DOB:	21/11/1961		UR:	8112354

																					

														

														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Ischaemic heart disease with ischaemic cardiomyopathy.
Significant burden of non-viability without scope for benefit with revascularisation procedures.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Family history of premature vascular coronary disease.
Ex-smoker.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Bisoprolol 10mg daily, Sacubitril – Valsartan 24/26mg 1 tablet twice daily, Empagliflozin 10mg daily, Spironalactone 25mg daily.
I reviewed Mark today.
He is stable.
NYHA class I – II.
No angina, no prolonged or pathological palpitations, no syncope and no episodes of cardiac decompensation.
We discussed his cardiac MRI results (LVEF 30%) and we also discussed the distribution of late gadolinium enhancement.
I discussed with him and his wife the potential role for a defibrillation to reduce his risk of sudden cardiac death.
I discussed that I will refer him to out Electrophysiology Team.

The specific potential benefits and risks will be discussed with him with our Electrophysiology Team; however, we did discuss in broad terms what a defibrillator involves, including the potential risks and benefits.
We discussed that the defibrillation will not improve his cardiac function but its serves as backup mechanism to reduce his risk of sudden death.

We discussed the potential risks of having a defibrillator implanted, including a 1 in 10 risk of inappropriate shocks as well as a 1 to 2% risk of device infection, requiring surgery and device removal.
The Qld Health Information and Consent form was also provided to Mark and his wife.
Blood pressure 118/75mmHg sitting and 129/76mmHg standing.
Heart rate 65bpm, respiratory rate 18, JVP not elevated heart sounds dual nil added, lung fields clear and no pitting peripheral oedema.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Increase Bisoprolol to 10mg daily (prescription provided).
Cease Ramipril from today and commence Sacubitril – Valsartan 24/26mg 1 tablet twice daily from 27.01.2023.
Ongoing heart failure nurse practitioner up titration of Sacutitril – Valsartan  with Christine Houghton via Ipswich Hospital.
Electrophysiology referral regarding potential suitability for implantable cardioverter defibrillator.
Repeat cardiology review in my clinic in 6 months.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Holburn,





RE:	JASON BELL		DOB:	25/06/1982		UR:	2130782

								

	



Mr Jason Bell came for an elective cardioversion today for atrial fibrillation and associated cardiomyopathy.
He takes Amiodarone 200mg daily, Bicor 3.75mg daily, Apixaban 5mg bd.
He has been compliant with his medications including anticoagulation.
He was in AF at the beginning of the procedures at 62bpm.
Cardiac MRI in June of 2022 showed LVEF of 46% with no evidence of infiltration or fibrosis and not unexpectedly, biatrial dilatation.
He underwent DCCV with 200 joules of synchronised current with reversion to sinus bradycardia initially to 28bpm and was given 600mg Iv atropine.
His HR  improved over 5min to 48 to 50bpm in sinus rhythm.
At time of review for discharge his HR was 52bpm.
His post cardioversion ECG showed sinus bradycardia at 45bpm with QRS 103ms, QTC 438ms and normal PR interval of 176ms.
I have continued his medications as is but advised him to reduce his bicor to 2.5mg daily and if he feels dizzy and his HR is below 45bpm.
He is young and asymptomatic from lower HR and needs therapy for his LV dysfunction.
He has a clinic follow up with Dr Ahmad coming up soon.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor,





														RE:	RONALD M. BENDALL	DOB:	21/11/1945	UR:	354578

																					

														

														

														I saw Ron in my clinic for follow up today.
He has been stable from the cardiac point of view over the last few months.
In terms of his angina, he complains of chest tightness / heaviness once every few months.

His background is significant for likely underlying coronary artery disease for medical therapy only, Childs Pugh B liver cirrhosis with previous variceal bleed, permanent atrial fibrillation (not for anticoagulation), hypertension, untreated obstructive sleep apnoea and GORD.
His current medications include Carvedilol 12.5mg bd, Digoxin 125mcg daily, Spironolactone 50mg daily, Frusemide 40mg bd, Thiamine 100mg daily, Folic Acid 5mg daily, and Esomeprazole 20mg prn.
He has no allergies.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 55bpm irregularly irregular, and his blood pressure was 100/60mmHg.
There was minimal bilateral pitting oedema.
His lasting fasting LDL cholesterol was 2.5mmol/L.
Today, I have started Ron on low dose Atorvastatin 10mg daily.
I have given him a pathology request form at S & N to keep an eye on his liver function tests next month.
I will see him in March for follow up with the intention of starting him on Ezetimibe at that time.
Thank you for looking after Ron.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Khurshid,







														RE:	PATSY BESWICK		DOB:	23/12/1969		UR:	8077253

																					

														

														

														Past Medical History:
# Severe rheumatic mitral stenosis.

- Successful percutaneous balloon mitral valvuloplasty (PBMV) - 28 mm Nucleus 

														       X balloon - 4 dilations
     - TTE Oct 2022 EF 60%, mild RV dilatation, rheumatic MV with severe MS mean

														       gradient 12mmHg, mild MR, elevated pulmonary pressures.
- CTCA Nov 2022 - ca.
score 23, non-obstructive CAD.
# Dyslipidaemia.
# Class II obesity.
# COPD.
# Previous nicotine dependence (>40 pack years).
# Incidental 7mm subpleural RML nodule May 2022.
- For F/up CT 6-12 months and 18-24 months.
# R MCA stroke May 2022.

# Multinodular goitre
   - Benign FNA, d/c from ENT OPD.

Medications:
clopidogrel 75mg mane (stopped today), aspirin 10mg daily, atorvastatin 80mg mane, NovoRapid 6 units with meals (1-2x/day), Oral hypoglycaemic agents ceased due to reported pruritis

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Patsy Beswick in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today, accompanied by her daughter and grandchild.
This was an additional unscheduled appointment to address some concerns that have arisen since her recent discharge from hospital after a percutaneous balloon mitral valvuloplasty.
Patsy tells me today that since the procedure, she has had intermittent sporadic fine tremors of her right upper and lower limbs.
This is also associated with paraesthesia.
If this fine tremor were to occur when standing, she would likely fall.
She has also had trouble walking since leaving hospital and is now walking with a limp, though she denies any pain on mobilisation.
She denies also any change in sensation in either her right upper or lower limb.
Patsy has not had any syncopal episodes since leaving hospital.
She reports a single episode of presyncope, which she has put down to having stood up too quickly.

After the balloon valvuloplasty, Patsy has had a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram which showed normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of approximately 60% by visual estimation.
She had a normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
After the balloon valvuloplasty, the transvalvular gradients were only mildly elevated, being measured at 6mmHg, at 73bpm.
There was only trivial mitral regurgitation.
The mitral valve area by 2D planimetry on the study was 2.6cm².
On examination, Patsy appeared well.
She mobilised slowly and cautiously with what appeared to be an antalgic gait, but as mentioned she denies any discomfort.
Her blood pressure today was 95/60mmHg and her heart rate was 64bpm and regular.
This corresponded with an ECG in sinus rhythm with similar waveforms to previous.
Patsy also tells me that her blood pressure is usually in the mid-90s and that she is largely asymptomatic of this.
Her neurological examination today was grossly intact.
She had a mild weakness in the right leg strength with most muscle groups testing at 4+ / 5 strength.
Her left leg was 5/5 in all muscle groups.
Her upper limb examination was unremarkable.
She had no cranial nerve deficits.
In discussion with Dr Cox, we do not have an explanation at present for her right sided symptoms.
There is a possibility that it is a prolonged residual effect of anaesthetic, but it may also be a complication of the procedure.

Therefore, I have asked her to see you in approximately 1 to 2 weeks of review of her right sided symptoms, and should these be persistent, to consider the utility of a CT brain to investigate this further.
In the meantime, we have asked Patsy to cease her Clopidogrel but to continue Aspirin indefinitely.
I have also encouraged her to renew her efforts in optimising her glycaemic control and have explained to her at length the many effects that it can have on her physiology including on her valves.
We will arrange to see Patsy again in approximately 6 weeks.

However, should her symptoms resolve, and she is feeling well, we have asked her to consider calling the Cardiology Outpatient Service and postponing her appointment to approximately 3 to 4 months from now.

We will write to you again at the time of her next appointment

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Mrs Beswick

														

														Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Pattabiraman, 





RE:	JOHN BIRD		DOB:	09/01/1938		UR:	090047

							



														

														Cardiac Background:

														Ischaemic heart disease.- PCI to D1.
-Moderate LAD disease.
-Mild circumflex and mild RCA disease in 2015.

Other medical B/G

														Sleep apnoea.
Peptic ulcer disease.
Hypertension.
Obesity.
Ex-smoker – 56 pack  year history.
Severe COPD with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg a day, Atorvastatin 40mg a day, Irbesartan / Thiazide 300/12.5mg once a day, Rabeprazole 20mg a day, Tiotropium Salbutamol puffers.
I had the pleasure of meeting John in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
He was admitted to MAPU Cardiology Unit in November 2022, with atypical episodes of chest pain and serial troponin was negative.

This has been further investigated with an echocardiogram, reporting preserved LV function 55% by visual estimation, normal RV size and systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation with dilated aortic root 40mm and ascending aorta 44mm.
Since discharge from hospital, John had 1 further episode of chest pain.
In the description, this pain is quite sharp in nature and lasted for 5 to 10 minutes, however, it did respond to GTN spray.
As he has severe COPD, his exercise limitations are quite poor, and he does not do much exertion.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 140/80mmHg, heart sounds were dual with no murmur and breath sounds were reduced.
It seems that John may have underlying intermittent atypical chest pain episodes with a prior history of ischemic heart disease.
However, given the extensive nature of his breathing condition, 85 years of age, and minimal burden of symptoms, , it is reasonable to continue with medical management.
I do note that he was discharged on Isosorbide Mononitrate 60mg from hospital.

However, this was stopped because 



RE:	JOHN BIRD		DOB:	09/01/1938		UR:	090047

														

														of low blood pressure.
If he has any increasing symptoms of angina, he may restart on 30mg of Isosorbide Mononitrate and depending on the blood pressure response, can be considered for uptitration.
I have refrained to start beta blocker given his extensive COPD history.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

I have rebooked him for a review in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic at the PA Hospital in 9 months  

														

														Thanking you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Connell,





RE:	LEONARD KERRY BIRD	DOB:	13/01/1946	UR:  661296

							



														Leonard attended heart failure titration clinic today.
He was referred on behalf of his Cardiologist, Dr Ahmad, for heart failure medication titration.
This is on the background of known heart failure with reduced ejection fraction which was likely AF/rate induced.
This was first diagnosed in 2018, his ejection fraction was 33%.
His EF subsequently improved in 2019 to 49% along with Leonard’s symptoms.
However, in 2021 his ejection fraction reduced back down, and he also developed a left bundle branch block.
Discussions were had about cardiac re-synchrony therapy and he is due to have a CRT-P inserted on the 31st January 2023.
His most recent echocardiogram on the 3rd January 2023 showed normal left ventricular size with moderate global systolic dysfunction, LVEF 31%.
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
Mild aortic and mitral regurgitation.
Leonard’s coronary angiogram in December 2019 showed angiographically normal coronary arteries.
His other medical history includes chronic atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, BPH, bowel cancer (1993) in which he underwent a resection and as result has intermittent lose stools.
He undergoes regular colonoscopies at the QEII Hospital.
He also has Prostatomegaly.

Medications

														Entresto 24/26mg BD, Bisoprolol 2.5mg mane, Xarelto 20mg mane, Duodart 500mcg/400mcg nocte, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Frusemide 40mg PRN, Somac 40mg nocte, Nizatidine 150mg BD, Magnesium daily, Zinc forte 1 tab twice a week, Turmeric one casual daily, CoQ10 daily.
Thank you for arranging a blood test with 4cyte pathology since the commencement of Spironolactone on the 10th December 2022.
These show a stable renal function with Na 141, K+ 4.9, urea 9.0, creat 94, and eGFR 68.
I repeated his blood test today (attached for your records), his renal function continues to be stable with Na 143, K+ 4.8, urea 7.7, creat 88, and eGFR 73.
On examination his blood pressure was 136/70mmHg with no postural drop, heart rate 70bpm and irregular.
He had no peripheral oedema.
JVP was negative, his lungs were clear and heart sounds were dual.

RE:	LEONARD KERRY BIRD	DOB:	13/01/1946	UR:  661296

														

														

														

														Today Leonard is euvolemic and his renal function remains stable with the commencement of Spironolactone.
I have asked him to increase the Entresto to 49/51mg nocte and leave his morning dose at 24/26mg.
He will likely have a routine CHEM20 during his admission on the 31st January for his CRT-P which will ensure his renal function has remained stable with the increasing of the Entresto.

However, if for some reason his admission does not occur, I would appreciate you checking his renal function in two weeks

														

														I will see him back in this clinic in five weeks.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Dissanayake,





														RE:	RODNEY BLACK		DOB:	25/07/1981		UR:	2234378

																					

														

														It was a pleasure to review Rodney in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 41-year-old gentleman who had an episode of dizziness last year, which he describes as vertigo, whilst driving.
The room was moving around him and he felt disorientated.
There was no presyncope and he did not feel as if he would lose consciousness.
There was no associated nausea or vomiting.
There was no associated chest pain or palpitations.
The episode lasted a few minutes and resolved spontaneously.
After this he continued to experience intermittent episodes of similar symptoms over a couple of months, usually while he was seated and often while he was watching a screen.
He has had none this year.
He denies any chest pain, palpitations or new dyspnoea on exertion.

This occurs on a background of:

														Obesity.
Hypertension.
LDL 3.0mmol/L.
His current medications are Candesartan 32mg and Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 143/89mmHg.
ECG showed him to be in sinus rhythm at 73bpm with poor anterior R-wave forces and some inferior Q-waves.
Heart sounds were dual with no murmur, his chest was clear and he had no peripheral oedema.
Recent full blood count, ELFT’s and chest x-ray by yourself were unremarkable.
In summary, I think Rodney’s symptoms were non-cardiac and they have now resolved.
They may have been consistent with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo.
The only investigation which may be reasonable for Rodney is a transthoracic echocardiogram, given his slightly abnormal ECG.
He would prefer if you could refer him for this somewhere locally, rather than having to return to the hospital.
Therefore, I have not made a routine appointment to see him again but would be more than happy to do so with any new issues or concerns in the future.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Deed,



RE:	MARCEL BLACKBURN	DOB:	24/08/1976	UR:  864983

							



														Marcel returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
Overall he has been quite well.
I understand that he had emergency department presentation on the 4th January 2023 for dehydration.
Marcel reports a stable weight at 94.7kg on his home scales.
He has had no PND or orthopnoea.
He reports NYHA class I symptoms and was able to walk up the Princess Alexandra Hospital hill today without having to stop.
He does get very occasional postural dizziness on standing quickly, this resolves within seconds.
Thank you for arranging a blood test with QML on the 13th January 2023.
These showed digoxin level of 1.7, which I understand was about 6 hours after his last digoxin dose.
Na 138, K+ 3.8, urea 5.8, creat 115, eGFR 65, which are around base line for him.

Medications

														Digoxin 250mcg mane (reduced to 125mcg mane today), Plavix 75mg mane, Entresto 49/51mg BD (increased today to 49/51mg mane and 97/103mg nocte), Spironolactone 25mg mane, Frusemide 40mg BD, Paroxetine 20mg nocte, GTN PRN, Atrovent PRN, Panadol PRN.
Marcel should be on Rosuvastatin 10mg however, he still has not started, he is feeling hesitant due to having nausea, vomiting and a tremor when taking Atorvastatin in the past.
On examination his blood pressure was 124/67mmHg sitting and 125/65mmHg standing, heart rate 91bpm and regular.
He had no peripheral oedema, and his lungs were clear.
Today on looking at Marcel’s blood test his total cholesterol was 6.0.
As you know on his angiogram in May 2022, he did have a first diagonal CAD.
Therefore, I have spoken to Marcel about the importance of restarting his Statin today.
He has agreed to trial Rosuvastatin, he will half the 10mg and take it at 5mg for one week and then increase it on the second week as long as he is not experiencing any symptoms.
Given Marcel’s digoxin level remains elevated at 1.7, I have asked him to half his digoxin to 125mcg.
We are aiming for a level of < 0.9 I have also increased the Entresto in the evening to 97/103mg, the morning dose will remain at 49/51mg.
I have provided him with a QML blood test request slip to have on Thursday 2nd February 2023.
I will call him on Friday 3rd to review his digoxin level and Chem 20 with these changes to his medications.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Chris,





RE:	NOEL BOUGHEN		DOB:	02/02/1966		UR:	2222105

							



														

														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Diabetic pan-vasculopathic negatively remodelled calcific diffuse branch vessel and distal vessel coronary artery disease.
a.

No scope for prognostic or symptomatic benefit from surgical or percutaneous coronary intervention

														

														Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Type II diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.
Family history of coronary artery disease.

Other Conditions:

														Chronic normocytic anaemia.
Tendency to hyperkalaemia / renal tubular acidosis type 4.

Medications:

														Aspirin 100mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily (commenced on review on 09.01.2023, Amlodipine 10mg daily, Empagliflozin / Metformin as directed, Gliclazide as directed.

Adverse drug reactions: ACEi/ARB/MRA/ARNI (hyperkalaemia)

														

														I reviewed Noel Boughen today.
Noel has terminal / branch vessel pan diabetic vasculopathy on invasive coronary angiography.
He has had no definite angina.
He does have some non-specific dyspnoea with an NYHA class II functional status.
He has had no syncope.
He does not drink alcohol.
He lives at home with his wife.
He works as an Electrician.

On examination his blood pressure was 144/73mmHg, heart rate 85bpm, respiratory rate 18, JVP was not elevated, heart sounds were dual nil added, lung fields were clear, abdomen was soft and non-tender, no evidence of abdominal aortic aneurysm and no pitting peripheral oedema.
His 12 Lead ECG demonstrates sinus rhythm 89bpm.
Most recent LDL cholesterol 2.0mmol/L.
I had a detailed discussion with Noel.
We reviewed his coronary angiography together.
It does not seem apparent that percutaneous coronary intervention in this setting would offer any symptomatic or prognostic / survival benefit.
The nature of his disease is calcified, distal vessel disease predominantly.

There is no focal 



RE:	NOEL BOUGHEN		DOB:	02/02/1966		UR:	2222105

														

														proximal vessel disease that would benefit from percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
Noel has a genetic cardiometabolic syndrome.
He would potentially benefit from the addition of a PCSK9 inhibitor.
He has commenced ezetimibe today.

I have given him a QML request form to have his lipid study repeated in 12 weeks and if his LDL cholesterol remains greater than 1.8mmol/L, the plan would be to commence him on Evolocumab by subcutaneous injection once per month.

Plan and Recommendations:

														Optimal medical therapy for coronary artery disease (and accepting inability to take ACE inhibitor / ARB.

Ezetimibe 10mg daily (prescription provided) with plan for fasting lipid study in April of this year and repeat review in May of this  year with a view to commencement of evolocumab should LDL remain >1.8mmol/L.

With kind regards,

Dear Dr Mahmood,





														RE:	NADER BOUKHARI		DOB:	22/04/1979		UR:	1156079

																					

														

														

														I saw Nader in my clinic for follow up today.
He has been well and asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view over the last 2 years.
He has been regularly exercising in the gym and denied any exertional symptoms.
Nader asked about using Sildenafil for erectile dysfunction today.
He stated that he has difficulty in maintaining an erection.
His background is significant for ischaemic heart disease with previous infarcts in 2015 and 2018, hypercholesterolaemia, hypothyroidism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
His medications include Aspirin 100mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril 5mg daily, Ezetimibe / Atorvastatin 10/80mg daily, Thyroxine 100mcg daily, Pantoprazole 40mg prn, Sertraline 50mg daily.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 55bpm regular and his blood pressure was 110/80mmHg.
Today, I have organised Nader to have a repeat echocardiogram to reassess his LV function, as well as some routine blood tests including fasting lipid profile.
As for his erectile dysfunction, I have advised him that he can use Sildenafil, as he is currently asymptomatic from the cardiac point of view.
However, if he develops angina during sexual intercourse, he should not use GTN concurrently.
I will speak to him again after his echocardiogram.
Thank you for looking after Nader.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Bathula,

														

														

														RE:	JOYCE BOURNE		DOB:	21/12/1945		UR:	296216

																					

														77 Years 

														Background

														Mild aortic stenosis

														Hypertension

														PRES with seizure and hypoxic respiratory arrest Dec 2022 in context of hypertension (sBP 224mmHg)

														Essential tremor

														

														Medications

														Lercanidipine 10mg BD

														Propranolol 10mg BD

														Pantoprazole 40mg

														Irbesartan 75mg commenced today.
Previous telmisartan ceased 2022 due to hyperkalaemia and AKI.
Previous hydrochlorothiazide ceased 2022 due to hyponatraemia.
Unclear reaction to quinapril.

Review

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Mrs Bourne in Dr Cox's Cardiology clinic today.
Mrs Bourne had a stormy end to her 2022 with her admission with PRES in the context of hypertensive emergency.
She has made a steady recovery since.
She is motivated keeping active and walks on a daily basis.
She can walk several hundred metres on the flat without issues though she uses a single point stick and is slow to mobilise.
Mrs Bourne reports inconsistent exertional chest pain on a monthly basis that lasts no longer than several seconds.
This never occurs at rest.
It does not bother her and does not limit her - she always continues walking and the pain will resolve.
It is pinpoint with no radiation nor associated symptoms.
She reports it can occur at different levels of exertion but is infrequent and is not reproducible with the same level of exertion/exercise.
Mrs Bourne has intermittent presyncope that correlates with hypertension.
She has not had any syncopal episodes.
Home blood pressures are done twice a day.
This year's systolic blood pressures have ranged 130-170mmHg at night and 130-150mmHg in the mornings at home.
On examination, Mrs Bourne appeared frail and required some time and her single point stick to perform a sit-to-stand.
BP was 144/70mmHg with no postural drop and no difference between her left and right arms.
She was clinically euvolaemic.
She has an ejection systolic murmur that radiates to her neck.
Her second heart sound is not muffled and she has normal carotid upstroke.
Transthoracic echocardiogram 8/12/22 at Ipswich Hospital showed normal biventricular size and function with mild aortic stenosis.
Ambulatory blood pressure QML 10/1/23 mean blood pressure 161/86mmHg with predominant nocturnal hypertension.

Impression

														Slow to progress mild aortic stenosis.
Poorly controlled hypertension and history of severe end organ dysfunction from hypertension.
Chest discomfort atypical for angina.

Plan

														I have commenced Mrs Bourne on Irbesartan 75mg OD today (half tab of 150mg tablet to reduce cost).
I note her telmisartan was ceased at Ipswich Hospital last year when she was hyperkalaemia but after detailed review of that admission, there were several confounders of her situation.
As such, I think it is reasonable to retrial ARB in the first instance.

I have given Mrs Bourne a pathology form to have her renal function and potassium checked one week after commencing irbesartan and I have asked for her to make an appointment with yourself to follow this up.
If she tolerates the irbesartan, it should be uptitrated to achieve average blood pressure <140/90mmHg.
If she has recurrent AKI/hyperkalaemia above 5.5mmol/L, it should be discontinued.
I think diltiazem would be a reasonable next agent if her heart rate remains above 60bpm.
We will leave Mrs Bourne's ongoing hypertension management with you, and we will review Mrs Bourne again in two years with a serial TTE to monitor her aortic stenosis.
Should she require an earlier review, please do not hesitate to contact our team.
Thank you for your time.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Henricks,





RE:	NOEL GAVIN BOURNE	DOB:	18/08/1956	UR:	441133

							



														

														It was a pleasure to review Noel in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
As you know he is a 66-year-old gentleman who was admitted in November with a single episode of troponin negative chest pain.
He then represented a few days later with an infective exacerbation of COPD.
He has subsequently undergone an outpatient exercise stress echocardiogram on 05.012.2023.
He exercised for 6 minutes reaching 95% of his maximum predicted heart rate and was limited by dyspnoea.
There were no ECG changes or inducible wall motion abnormalities to suggest cardiac ischaemia.
His pulmonary pressures were at the upper limit of normal at rest and rose with exercise.
I think this would all be consistent with COPD.
Noel has had no further chest pain since discharge.
After a prolonged course of oral antibiotics his breathing improved and best of all, he has stopped smoking.
In summary, I think Noel’s dyspnoea is related to his lung disease and there is no evidence of inducible ischaemia.
He has had no further chest pain.
I do not think he requires any further cardiac investigations at this stage.
I have told him that he can cease Aspirin and his statin.
I have asked him to continue seeing you for risk factor monitoring and possible investigation of his lung disease.
Many thanks for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 25.01.23

														Dear Dr Weerasinghe,

														

														

														RE:	MALETINA BROWN		DOB:	17/01/1977		UR:	680461

																					

														

														

														Issues:
1.
Rheumatic heart disease.
· Mitral valve repair 2003.
Permanent atrial fibrillation.
Permanent pacemaker for tachy brady syndrome 2019.
Hypertension.
GORD.
Menorrhagia.

· Associated with iron deficiency
    · Endometrial ablation in February 2021, due to ADR towards mirena
    · No further menorrhagia.

Medications:
Metoprolol 100mg bd, Verapamil 80mg bd, Apixaban 5mg bd, Digoxin 250mcg, frusemide 40mg mane.

No missed doses

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Maletina Brown in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
She is known to this clinic for rheumatic heart disease on a background of permanent atrial fibrillation and sick sinus syndrome for which a permanent pacemaker was implanted in 2019.
Up until the last clinic appointment, her atrial fibrillation was refractory to therapy.
However, she tells me today that since the medications were titrated further, as well as the addition of Digoxin 250mcg per day, she seems to have achieved adequate control.
She is very diligent in taking her medications and does not miss any doses.
With respect to the atrial fibrillation, she describes no significant shortness of breath out of keeping with her level of activity.
She feels that her atrial fibrillation is now well controlled, and the medications are working very well.

She also denies any significant chest discomfort except when she has a short run of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and this is reliably managed by taking her usual rate limiting medications.
Her most recent transthoracic echocardiogram was done in December last year.
This showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an ejection fraction of approximately 60%.
There was a normal right ventricular size and low normal systolic function.
The mitral valve repair was noted with trace mitral regurgitation.
Mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation was also seen.
I understand that at the last clinic appointment, there were concerns about high burden of ectopic beats.
As a result, I have asked the Pacemaker Clinic to check her pacemaker today, as no remote uploads have occurred since September last year.
The outcome of the check today showed that remote monitoring is continuing to work.
The lead voltages and impedance are all within target range and that the device had more than 11 years battery remaining.
The average number of premature ventricular contractions remains at 9.9 per hour between September and the present day.
On examination today, Maletina appears well and in good spirits.
Her blood pressure was 120/75mmHg and her heart rate was 76bpm.
Her chest was clear, and her heart sounds were dual with  no  murmur.
There was no peripheral oedema.
As Maletina feels that her rate is now adequately controlled with her currently regimen of  medications, I have not made any changes.
However, should her condition change, especially with increasing difficulty in managing her atrial fibrillation rate, I would ask that you please write to us to move her appointment accordingly.
I have also encouraged her to have routine annual check ups with you regularly, including pathology and other tests as appropriate.
I will arrange to review Maletina again in approximately 18 months and should she remain stable at that time, we may consider discharging her from clinic.
Thank you for your ongoing care for Ms Brown.

Yours sincerely,

I had the pleasure of catching up with Mr Bryant in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.

														Dear Davood ,





RE:	CHRISTINE CALVISI		DOB:	12/02/1973		UR:	063251

							



														

														It was a pleasure to catch up with Christine in the Cardiology Clinic today.
I am pleased to report that her CT coronary angiogram was pristine, showing a calcium score of 0 and no plaque in her arteries.
She actually  had a CTPA on that day also which was normal.
She did not like the Fludrocortisone at all, although she could not be specific about the side effects.
She just said she was not with it and it did not agree.
She went on to say that  most medicines do not agree with her.
She feels like she is going through menopause, and this could be contributing.
Certainly, vasomotor instability is a common side effect of menopause.
She could also have POTS.
Most of her symptoms fit with this.
Whilst it would be unusual  to develop this late in life, she is quite slim which is a risk factor.
I have seen quite a bit of autonomic dysfunction following both long COVID infection and COVID vaccines.
Examination today revealed a blood  pressure of 105/60mmHg, dropping to 90/60mmHg with standing.
She did not like the Fludrocortisone.
I discussed the concept that we usually like to boost the blood pressure first to treat the orthostatic hypotension, before we treatment the tachycardia with Beta blockers.
If Fludrocortisone does not work, I usually try Midodrine.
The problems with this is that it is about $90 a month.
Christine does not feel like she could afford that.
In lieu of that, I have suggested she start taking some cheap over the counter salt tablets, to try to boost her blood pressure as well as drink 3 litres of water a day.
If that is enough to boost her blood pressure a bit, we could try a Beta blocker.
Sadly, I anticipate she will probably get side effects from that too, but I have discussed these with her.
She asked if she could stop the Aspirin and Nexium and I am fine with this.
I will see her again n 3 months.

Yours sincerely,

														It was a pleasure to review Chris in the Cardiology Clinic today.
He is a 67-year-old gentleman who presented to the PA Hospital in October last year with anaphylaxis to Cephalex.
This was used for groin abscess.
He required adrenaline and steroids, and he was on an adrenaline infusion.
In the setting of this, he developed atrial fibrillation and had widespread ST depression.
He had a troponin rise as well.
It all settled down when adrenaline infusion was stopped.
He usually does not get any exertional angina / dyspnoea, orthopnoea, PND or peripheral oedema.
He is a current smoker and has smoked for the last 30 to 40 years.
He has been on antihypertensives for the last 6 to 8 years.
He has also been on Crestor for a few years.
He is obese.
On examination today he had no signs of heart failure.
His blood pressure was 140/80mmHg.
ECG shows sinus rhythm.
There is no voltage criteria for LVH.
In view of his risk factor profile and ST changes and troponin rise (type 2 myocardial infarction), I have suggested an echocardiogram and an exercise stress echocardiogram.
I will organise this for him at the PA Hospital.
Currently he is on Aspirin 100mg daily, Crestor 20mg daily, Atenolol 50mg daily, Telmisartan / Amlodipine 80/10mg daily.
I have stress upon the importance of smoking cessation for overall cardiovascular health.

Yours sincerely,

														Dear Dr Michael Clem,

														

														

														RE: DARREN CAMERON		DOB: 18/04/1974		UR: 1106821

														

														I had the pleasure of meeting Daren the 48-year-old gentlemen in Cardiology clinic this afternoon.
He has a known history of severe mitral regurgitation for which he is known to Dr Ura in CTS clinic and has been postponing his MV surgery due to work commitment issues.
Daren has quite an eventful year 2022 with multiple acute / chronic issues which I have listed below.

MSSA bacteremia in June 22 complicating MV IE 

														 Cardioembolic stroke in the setting of new diagnosis of AF 

														 Further complicated with posterior fossa subarachnoid haemorrhage while on anticoagulation for AF

														 Subsequent development of Obstructive hydrocephalus with surgical evacuation in September 2022 

														 Subsequent infection resulting in ventriculitis with long term antibiotic treatment

														 Disseminated Staph aureous infection leading to mitral valve infective endocarditis in June 2022

														 Has been seen in CTS clinic and is awaiting mitral valve surgery under cardiothoracic, currently has not been booked as of yet.

TTE Jan 2023 - Severe LV dilation with preserved ejection fraction EF 53%, normal RV size and systolic function, Anterior mitral valve leaflet prolapse and restricted posterior mitral valve leaflet with severe eccentric mitral regurgitation.

Cardiac  B/G

														Severe mitral regurgitation

														IHD - Distal RCA chronic total occlusion Pre op Angiogram in 2018

														pAF 

														Ex smoker 

														

														Other medical B/G

														Obesity

														NAFLD

														Gilberts syndrome

														Ileocolonic (Predominantly colonic) Crohn's disease

														diverticulum requiring Hartmann's procedure

														- Hartmann reversal February 2020

														- Closure loop ileostomy May 2020

														

														Medication list 

														Amiodarone 200mg once a day, bisoprolol 2.5mg mane, Pradaxa 110mg BD (however, he has been taking it once a day basis) digoxin 125mg mane, frusemide 80mg mane, 40mg in the noon, enalapril 10mg nocte, aspirin 100mg mane

														

														

														I have discussed the importance of adherence to medications with Darren.
He should be religiously taking the optimal dosing of 110 mg BD of Dabigatran given the history of  AF ,severe LA dilation and stroke.
Going through the documentation the choice of  Dabigatran is made given the availability of reversal agent.
On examination today his blood pressure was 120/70mmgHg, heart sounds were dual with a soft systolic murmur 3/6 radiating to axilla, there are no signs of volume overload.
At this stage I have not made any changes to medication, he is currently awaiting a CTS review.
I have advised him to continue on amiodarone and optimal dabigatran dosing which he has agreed too continue with.
I booked him for a phone review in 3months time to check if there is any progress.
Please continue your ongoing care and feel free to contact us for any other concerns inbetween.

Yours sincerely,

														Background:

														New atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate.
Admitted to the PA Hospital in September 2022.
Subsequent finding of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction – LVEF 40%.
Left sided breast cancer with surgical lumpectomy in 2000, followed by chemo-radio therapy.
Recent recurrence managed with left sided mastectomy.
Diverticular disease.
Benign multinodular goitre.
Non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Asthma.
Dyslipidemia.
Osteoarthritis.

Current Medications:

														Apixaban 5mg BD, Amiodarone 200mg mane, Metoprolol 25mg BD, Perindopril 1.25mg mane, Magmin supplements, Gliclazide 60mg mane, Metformin 1g nocte, Atorvastatin 40mg mane, Vitamin D supplements, Panadol PRN, Salbutamol PRN< Endone PRN.
I had the pleasure of meeting Molly with her daughter in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
This was a scheduled cardiology clinic review since her discharge from the PA Hospital in September 2022.
Molly overall has been doing reasonably well since her discharge.
She was scheduled for a DC cardioversion for atrial fibrillation management, however, due to the proposed left mastectomy and being off from NOAC, the DC cardioversion has been postponed.

Now she has recovered from her surgical mastectomy, and has resumed her Apixaban since 01.12.2022, since then she has missed 1 dose of Apixaban on Boxing Day, but otherwise has been adherent with this medication.
Her ECG was still in atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 94bpm.
On examination her blood pressure was 130/70mmHg, heart sounds were dual with no murmur, chest examination was clear.
I have discussed and explained the concept of DC cardioversion and both Molly and her daughter are keen to proceed with this.
She should be  medically optimised in the next 3 weeks for a possible cardioversion.
I have sent a referral for this, and we will get in touch with Molly for the upcoming cardioversion in the few weeks.
Please continue with your ongoing are and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.
We do a phone review with Molly in 3 months to check her clinic progression.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Yeh,





RE:	AI MEI CHEN		DOB:	08/01/1971		UR:	2108480

							





														Past History:

														?congenital complete heart block.
ECG today demonstrated completed heart block at a rate of 42bpm.
Long discussion today via a Cantonese interpreter and recommended a permanent pacemaker as Mrs Chen has developed some mild presyncope and fatigue.
She has had demonstrated chronotropic incompetence on exercise stress test.
She has had no frank syncope and we had a long discussion regarding a permanent pacemaker and her occupation.
I informed her that with soldering, this may interfere with the permanent pacemaker but otherwise, I believe there will be no problems if she can avoid doing this.
With regard to permanent pacemaker, we discussed the risks and benefits at length.
There is a 1 to 2% risk of complication including pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, haemorrhage and infection, the device can be subject to advisories.
She has no known allergies and no medications and happy to proceed and we will book this for her.
I believe her congenital heart block is gradually worsening and she is becoming increasingly bradycardic, and a permanent pacemaker is the appropriate treatment for this.
If your have any questions, please do not hesitate to get in touch with us.
Many thanks for your ongoing care of this patient.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Xiao,





														RE:	TSEMIN CHEN		DOB:	22/07/1950		UR:	8081563

																					

														

														

														Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Chen, a lovely 72-year-old Mandarin speaking gentleman who I had the pleasure of reviewing along side an interpreter, his wife and daughter.

His  medical issues include:

														Ischaemic heart disease.
Non-STEMI November 2020.
Invasive angiography revealed 2 vessel coronary artery disease (LAD and RCA).
Moderate LAD disease (FFR negative).
Severe mid RCA lesion (drug eluting stent).
Hypertension.
Treated dyslipidaemia.
Recent diagnosis of type II diabetes.
Never smoker.
His current medications include Irbesartan 75mg, Atorvastatin 40mg,  Aspirin 100mg, Clopidogrel 75mg, Ezetimibe 10mg and Metformin.
On review today, Mr Chen reports no chest pain, however, in the last few months, he has begun to develop exertional dyspnoea, particularly when going up hills.
Despite his breathing difficulties, he is able to walk 4 to 5 kilometres every evening and denies any orthopnoea, PND, presyncope or syncope.
He denies an history of asthma or COPD.
On examination today, his blood pressure was 128/80mmHg, his heart sounds were dual with  no murmurs, and he was euvolaemic.
His echocardiogram performed in 2021, showed a normal LV size and systolic function with no significant valvular abnormalities.
I note that his recent blood tests were unremarkable, however a lipid profile was not performed.

Our impression today is that Mr Chen is stable from a cardiac status, however, given his exertional dyspnoea, we will organise an exercise stress echocardiogram to see if there is a cardiac cause for this.
I have also stopped his Clopidogrel today, as this was well overdue, however, he is to continue to on Aspirin lifelong.
We will perform a phone review with him in 6 months to follow up the results of his exercise stress echocardiogram.
I have reiterated the chest pain pathway to Mr Chen.
Please keep an eye on his lipid profile and ensure that his LDL is <1.4.
Please increase his atorvastatin if his results are not within target range.
Thank for your ongoing care and please do not hesitate in contacting us should you  have any questions or concerns.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Eric,





														RE:	JUSTIN CHROBAK		DOB:	23/02/1973		UR:	177272

																					

														

														Diagnoses:

														Persistent atrial fibrillation.
Ejection fraction 35%.
Ejection fraction 56% with mild to moderate MR November 2022.
Obstructive sleep apnoea (CPAP).

Medications:

														Entresto 49/51mg BD, Desvenlafaxine 50mg nocte, Metoprolol XL 142.5mg daily, Atorvastatin 20mg nocte, Dapagliflozin 10mg mane, Spironolactone 12.5mg mane, Allopurinol 100mg daily, Rivaroxaban 20mg once a day.
I saw Mr Chrobak after his previous care at the QEII Hospital.
Justine is a 49-year-old man, who was found to have atrial fibrillation and left ventricular dysfunction in March 2022.
He was treated with heart failure therapy and his ejection fraction improved from 35% to 55% on most recent assessment.
He has had multiple attempts at cardioversion, including with Amiodarone loading.
He had recurrence of his atrial fibrillation within 1 to 2 weeks.
In AF he has noticed shortness of breath and fatigue, though no palpitations.
There has been no syncope or presyncope.
On examination, his heart rate was 70bpm in AF.
His blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
Justin has had recurrent atrial fibrillation despite Amiodarone and there seems to be benefits in sinus rhythm for him, with his energy levels and exercise tolerance.
Pleasingly, he has normalised his LV function with his heart failure therapy.
I have spoken with him regarding an AF ablation as the most successful treatment for atrial fibrillation.

We have discussed risks including bleeding and vascular access complications, as well as less frequently though more serious risks such as stroke, atrioesophageal fistular or serious damage to cardiac structures.
Justin would like to go on to an AF ablation and I will arrange this for him, though I have cautioned of out significant waiting list for this.
In the interim I have continued him on his  heart failure therapy.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Wang, 





														RE:	GEOFFREY WINTER CLARKE	DOB:	14/09/1935	UR:	2235403

																					

														

														

														Thank you for referring Mr Clarke.
He is an 87-year-old man who has lives on the island of Jersey for many years.
His wife is Australian, and they moved back to Australia as they have family here.
Apparently, he is undergoing an immigration assessment at the moment.
He walks with a 3-wheeled walker, because of previous knee surgery and spine problems.
He says he can walk 100 to 200 metres without stopping, but then becomes breathless and fatigued and needs to sit down.
He has similar problems if he does stand still for a prolonged period.
He has a history of a left mastectomy for a localised breast cancer which received hormone suppressive therapy only.
He has had diabetes for many many years, and a most recent HbA1c is 8.7%.
I note that a CT scan of brain was organised with the request stating cognitive impairment.
Today, his MSQ is 7/10, but I would note that his he is a foreigner, so not knowing the suburb, the Prime Minister or the past Prime Minister, might give him some leeway.
Clinically he is obese at 92 kilograms.
He has some very mild peripheral oedema in the right left appose to the left.
He has fibrotic crackles at both lung bases.
He has 2 to 3 / 6 ejection murmurs with a moderate reduction in carotid volumes.
The radial pulses are intact.
The 12 Lead ECG shows sinus rhythm at 60bm with left ventricular hypertrophy and strain.
His blood pressure was 133/68mmHg, oxygen saturations 97% at rest, his pulse was 60bpm and regular.
Mr Clarke is on appropriate medications.
He is having his diabetes reviewed.
I would suggest some formal lung function testing and a chest XRay, if that has not been performed.
His echocardiogram that you have kindly supplied, shows moderate aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.2cm² and a mean gradient of 24mmHg.
I believe he is breathless, probably from underlying lung disease (ex-smoker with 25 pack year history), obesity, orthopaedic limitations and his aortic stenosis.
The latter would not require intervention at this stage.
I will arrange to see him in 1 year with an echocardiogram performed here at the hospital.
Thank you for involving me in his care.

Yours sincerely,

														Scott returned to heart failure titration clinic today.

He is having some difficulties at home related to his adult stepson living with them.
He is quite fearful about the future and his condition.
He is concerned that he might drop dead at any stage.
Scott is working, he tells me that he worked about 14 hours yesterday.
He denies any breathlessness.
He does get occasional postural light headedness and he denies any chest pain.

Medications

														Ramipril increased to 10mg daily, Carvedilol 6.25mg BD, Spironolactone 25mg daily.

On examination his blood pressure was 155/100mmHg sitting and 160/100mmHg standing, heart rate 64bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have increased the Ramipril to 10mg mane.
I have asked him to come back and see me in four weeks.
I have provided him a blood test request slip to have prior to seeing me.
I had a long discussion with him today about his low mood.
He has agreed have a discussion with you about the options for managing this.

														Medical Issues:
1.

Dilated cardiomyopathy 

															– non-obstructive CAD Feb 2022, LVEF 35-40%; 

															-  now recovered on latest TTE in November 2022
2.

Previous methamphetamine use – now quit
3.

Current marijuana use – infrequent
4.

Previous excess alcohol use - now cut down
5.

Smoker – cut down to 1-2 cigarettes/day

Medications:
Aspirin 100mg daily, Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Bisoprolol 5mg BD, Frusemide 20mg PRN, Ramipril 10mg daily, Spironolactone 12.5mg daily, Dapagliflozin 10mg daily

														

														Review:

														I reviewed Mr Glegg along with his partner, in Dr Singbal’s Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today at the PA Hospital.
He is doing quite well, NYHA class II.
He is exerting himself up to 1 kilometre without any issues.
He does get occasional breathlessness, but this is much improved from before.
He has no chest pain, palpitations or syncope.
He remains compliant with his medications and remains abstinent from methamphetamine use and excessive alcohol.
Pleasingly, his LVEF has now recovered on the current medications and ongoing abstinence from substance.

Plan

- Continue statin at high dose indefinitely (secondary prevention for non-obstructive coronary disease) 
- Continue HF medicines
- Abstain from substance/EtOH use
- Discharge from clinic given stable on tablets + recovered LVEF
- Ongoing follow up with GP, re-referral back if deterioration in symptoms/other concerns

Dear Doctor,





RE:	GLEN DOUGLAS COBB	DOB:	03/07/1962	UR:	410713

							



														Background:
1.
Ischaemic heart disease.
- CABG and Mechanical AVR in 2013 (25mm ATS).
- Previous PCI to mid circumflex and RCA.
Testicular cancer (seminoma), with bilateral orchiectomy and chest radiotherapy.
Thyroid cancer with total thyroidectomy.
Asthma.

Obstructive sleep apnoea - severe
    - known to PAH sleep clinic
    - on CPAP - titrated down by sleep clinic, but still experiencing bloating

Medications:
warfarin 8mg daily, isosorbide mononitrate SR 60mg mane, atorvastatin 80mg nocte, pantoprazole 40mg mane, levothyroxine 150microg mane Sat/Sun, 125microg M-Fri, Symbicort 400/12 BD, salbutamol PRN, paracetamol PRN, testosterone IM every 4 weeks

														

														I had the pleasure of speaking with Glen Cobb today in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
This is consultation was done via telephone today.
Glen is known to us for history of ischaemic heart disease that was treated with coronary artery bypass grafting with a concurrent mechanical AVR performed in 2013.
Since his last review, Glen has been well.
He was in good spirits today on the phone, enjoying a coffee at the time of the call.
He has now been working as a delivery driver for the last few months, with is an active job.
Despite his physical requirement of the job, he has not experienced any chest discomfort, presyncope, or syncopal episodes.
He also denied any orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.
His most recent transthoracic echocardiogram was in November last year.
This showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with an LVEF measured at 59% by Simpson’s method.
He had a normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
His mechanical aortic valve replacement appeared well seated with satisfactory function.
There was trivial paravalvular regurgitation.
He also had mild mitral regurgitation seen on this study.
Glen has been stable for several years and with the recent stabilisation of his circumstances,  he has re-joined BUPA private insurance and intends to return to his private Cardiologist.

RE:	GLEN DOUGLAS COBB	DOB:	03/07/1962	UR:	410713

														

														I have made no changes to Glen’s current medication regimen today.
I have encouraged him to continue regular screening tests with you, his GP, to ensure his LDL remains <1.4 and to have diabetes screening and subsequent management should it become an issue.
Given Glen’s stability and intension to return to regular appointments with his previous private Cardiologist, we will discharge him from this clinic at this time.
We would be happy for Glen to be re-referred to us should this be required in the future.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Cobb.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 12.01.23

														Dr Jonathan Sen

														Cardiology Registrar for

														

														Associate Professor Arnold Ng

														Consultant Cardiologist

														Dr S Chupungco

														Logan Central Medical Centre

														1 Wembley Road

														LOGAN CENTRAL QLD 4114

														

														

														

														Dear Dr Chupungco,

														

														

														RE:	AJSHE COCAJ		DOB:	02/10/1953		UR:	345557

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Atypical chest pain
   - previously known to Dr. N Dwivedi
   - CTCA diffuse atherosclerotic disease with moderate LAD disease, potential

														     severe OM disease, diffuse mild RCA disease (CTCS 603)
   - TTE normal LV function with mild concentric LV hypertrophy
   - ESE negative for inducible ischaemia (Sept 2022)
# Hypertension
# Dyslipidaemia
   - previous statin-induced myopathy to high dose statin

Medications:
aspirin 100mg daily, hydralazine 12.5mg daily (stopped today), ramipril 2.5mg daily (started today), verapamil SR 120mg daily
vitamin D supplement, simvastatin/ezetimibe 40/10mg daily, clonazepam 1mg (for sleep)

														Note: documented elevated CK (155) to high dose statin (?pravastatin/simvastatin)

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Ajshe Cocaj in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.
She was known to this clinic for investigation of atypical chest pain on the background of hypertension and dyslipidaemia.
Since our last review, Ajshe tells me that she continues to experience chest heaviness when she sleeps at night, usually walking her up from sleep at ~3am.
This is relieved after she fully awakens from sleep and is associated with acid brash or a bad taste in her mouth.
As previously mentioned, her chest discomfort usually occurs when she is laying supine.
In September last year, Ajshe had an exercise stress echocardiogram that showed a normal left ventricular size and systolic function at rest with an LVEF of 55%.
There were no resting regional wall motion abnormalities, but there was an increased left ventricular wall thickness.
Mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation was seen on screening images with a mildly dilated ascending aorta at 38mm.
She exercised for 9 minutes and 32 seconds and achieved 89% of her maximum predicted heart rate and 10.8METs.
She did not experience any chest pain during the stress test.
Overall, the exercise stress echocardiogram was reported as negative for inducible ischaemia at the target heart, at above average workload for age.
The exercise stress echocardiogram result is reassuring that the chest discomfort that she is experiencing is unlikely to be cardiac in origin.
I understand that she has also had a carotid artery doppler performed at QXR, in April last year, showing 16 – 49% bilateral RCA stenosis.
This as well as the calcific atherosclerotic disease in her coronary arteries can be treated with statin therapy.
With effect to her previous experience with statins, I understand that high dose statin, though I am unclear as to which specific statin, she had a documented elevated CK at 155.
This was also associated with abnormal liver function test.
After discontinuing the medication for approximately 1 month, repeat LFT’s had returned to normal limits.
She now continues on Simvastatin and Ezetimibe 40/10mg daily.
She does not experience any myalgia with this dose.
However, I am unclear as to the steady state LDL level on this dose.
Her most recent pathology panel was performed in November last year.
The total cholesterol was 4.3mmol/L on this test - this was before the statin could reach study state.

There is some discrepancy in the documentation as to the specific statin that was used at the time of the statin induced myopathy, therefore, I have not taken the liberty of changing her statin therapy today.
However, I would ask that should her lipid profile show an LDL above 1.6, that you consider changing Simvastatin to Rosuvastatin.
I would start at 10mg Rosuvastatin concurrently with 10mg of Ezetimibe for 3 months with a repeat LDL and lipid profile to guide further gradual titration at that time.

This regimen may have already been attempted with adverse drug reaction; therefore, I would ask that you please adjust her medications to the maximum tolerated statin dose to a target LDL <1.6 as per prevention guidelines.
She also tells me that she has been feeling dizzy and tired recently.
Her blood pressure that she measures on her home monitor is approximately 90/50mmHg when she is taking both her Hydralazine and Verapamil.
She tells me that she has been self-titrating both the Hydralazine and Verapamil to the doses stated above.
I note that on her most recent pathology panel  her potassium was 4.6 and her eGFR was >90ml/min.
Therefore, I have taken the liberty of ceasing her Hydralazine and changing her to Ramipril 2.5mg nocte.
I have asked her to have a Chem 20 in one week, for which I have provided her pathology request form.
A copy of the results will be sent to you for further review.

I have also asked her to start a blood pressure log / diary on Monday, approximately 3 days after starting Ramipril and to bring that to your appointment for review and adjustment of her antihypertensive therapy as appropriate.
She inquired about the safety of travelling to Europe in August this year.

While at present, there may not be a contraindication from a cardiac perspective for her to travel, I have advised her to review her condition with you closer to the day of travel to assess her overall safety.
Finally, circling back to her atypical chest pain, which we think is gastric reflux, I have provided her with a script for Nizatidine 150mg twice daily.
I ask that you please review the efficacy of this H2 antagonist at your clinic appointment and if required, consider escalation to a PPI.
I have not made any follow up appointment for Ajshe to be seen again in this clinic.
However, should she require further cardiology input, please re-refer her to us at that time.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Ms Cocaj.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Tennekoon,





														RE:	KIRSTIN COCHRANE	DOB:	18/11/1996	UR:	2110035

																							

														

														

														Kirstin was reviewed today via telehealth from Roma Hospital.
She was excited to announce she was now 20 weeks pregnant and she went off Xarelto 4 to 5 months prior to conceiving which is appropriate.
Currently she is taking the recommended pregnancy supplements and feels well.
She gets the occasional which were more vehement during 1st trimester.
An event monitor during this time showed several patient events all of which corresponded to either sinus rhythm or sinus tachycardia at a rate of about 110 to 115bpm.
She is doing very well, her heart is structurally normal, she has had an ablation and there is no indication currently that her AF has recurred.
She prefers to birth locally by vaginal delivery and her delivery date early May 2023.

We will do a phone review in April, just to see how she is going, but I do not think she requires a high-risk pregnancy center or a controlled birth in the form of C-section at this point in time, given her stability and no evidence of concerning arrhythmia thus far.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Ng,





RE:	MICHAEL COCHRANE	DOB:	26/11/1973	UR:  8114167

							



														Michael attended the heart failure titration clinic today with his wife Miwa.
This is on the background of recent admission under General Medicine at the Princess Alexandra Hospital with severe fluid overload.
During this time Michael was newly diagnosed with heart failure reduced ejection fraction, likely ETOH induced.
Echocardiogram on the 7th December 2022 showed severely dilated LV with severe global systolic dysfunction.
LVEF 10%.
Dilated RV with impaired systolic function.
Moderate to severe functional MR and severe TR.
He was consulted by cardiology and commenced on Spironolactone, Ramipril and Bisoprolol.
He was also noted to have alcohol induced chronic liver disease and renal impairment.
During this admission repeat CT showed bilateral PE's, he was also noted to be iron deficient undergoing an infusion during his stay.
His past medical history includes a significant alcohol intake of 1L casket of red wine per day for the last 10 years up until Dec 2022 admission.
Ex-smoker ceased 10 years ago.
I understand he lives with his wife and his two children (13yo boy and 10yo girl).
Michael’s father, who has dementia, is also living with the family who share responsibilities in caring for him.
Michael owns his own car washing business in which he is currently on leave from, and he is applying to Centrelink for some assistance financially.

Medications

														Rivaroxaban 20mg daily, Digoxin 125mcg nocte, Ramipril 1.25mg 1/2 BD, Bisoprolol 2.5mg ¼ tab BD, Spironolactone 25mg mane, Pantoprazole 40mg nocte, Vitaminorum 1 mane, Thiamine 100mg mane, Cholecalciferol 25mcg mane, Magnesium 500mg mane.
Since discharge Michael has lost a further 12kg in weight, presumably fluid.
As such he self-stopped his 40mg Frusemide in the morning on the 5th January 2023.
His Spironolactone was also reduced to 25mg on the 9th January after during his Cardiac Rehabilitation assessment here last week.
Symptomatically he has been quite well.
He has had no PND or orthopnoea.
He can walk up his 20 internal stairs without any concerns.
He has not noticed any oedema, palpitations, or chest pain.
He has good appetite with no abdominal bloating.
His weight at home is 69kg.

RE:	MICHAEL COCHRANE	DOB:	26/11/1973	UR:  8114167

														

														

														Pleasingly since discharge Michael has continued to abstain from all alcohol.
On examination his blood pressure was 102/66mmHg sitting and 104/70mmHg standing, heart rate 80bpm and regular.
He has no peripheral oedema.
His lungs were clear, and heart sounds were dual.
His stomach was soft and non tender.
Blood test today show a normal renal function with Na 140, K+ 4.9, urea 6.6, creat 74, and eGFR >90.
His liver function is slowly returning to normal with a bilirubin of 5, Alkaline Phosphate of 121, Gamma-GT 142, Alanine Transaminase 45.
His phosphate level was elevated at 1.69 which is unusual for Michael.
These are attached for your records.
Michael is euvolemic today and managing quite well.
I have changed both his Ramipril and Bisoprolol doses to once daily to reduce the amount ½ and ¼ tablets he is taking.
Therefore, his Ramipril will be 1.25mg nocte and the Bisoprolol will move to morning only with an increased dose to 2.5mg.
I will see him back in this clinic in five weeks.
I may consider at that time reducing the Spironolactone to 12.5mg to allow for further titration of his medications.
Thank you for your ongoing care.

Yours sincerely, 









Emma Harmer

Nurse Practitioner

I reviewed Trevor in the Cardiology Clinic today.
Trevor has been doing really well.
There is no evidence of heart failure or exertional angina / dyspnoea.

I have reassured about this.

Dear Dr Jamali,





														RE:	JEFFREY A. COLEMAN	DOB:	05/03/1966	UR:	1101822

																					

														

														

														I saw Jeffrey in my clinic for follow up today.
His recent CRT-D check with Dr Kieran Dauber revealed ventricular tachycardia that was treated with ATP.
Jeffrey was completely unaware of the VT and denied any symptoms of palpitations or light headedness / syncope.
As for his repeat blood tests, it still showed poorly controlled type II diabetes with the HbA1c of 8.8%, and hypertriglyceridaemia with the fasting triglyceride at 47.5mmol/L.
Jeffrey denied any history of abdominal pains to suggest pancreatitis.
Finally, Jeffrey reassured me that he has been taking his medications regularly over the last few months.
His background is significant for cardiac sarcoidosis complicated by complete heart block and treated with CRT-D, type II diabetes, and previous CVA.
He has poor compliance with medications having stopped all his medications for extended periods at least twice in the past.
His current medications include Clopidogrel 75mg daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Ramipril 5mg daily and Rosuvastatin 40mg daily.
He has no allergies to his medications.
On examination today, his pulse rate was 65bpm regular and his blood pressure was 130/70mmHg.
Today, I have increased the Bisoprolol to 5mg daily, and restarted Metformin XR 1g daily and Fenofibrate 145mg daily.
I have given Jeffrey a repeat pathology request form to check his fasting lipids and HbA1c again in 3 months.
Finally, I have reminded Jeffrey to present to hospital if he experiences any discharges from his CRT-D.
I will see him again in 3 months for follow up.

Yours sincerely,

RE:	RITA MAY COLLINS		DOB:	19/03/1943		UR:	159117

							



														

														I had the pleasure of meeting Rita in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic this afternoon.
She was previously seen by Dr Singbal in December 2022, for work up of her exertional dyspnea.
She has been investigated with an echocardiogram, cardiac MRI and dobutamine stress echocardiogram so far.
She has had normal BNP and normal troponin.
On the CT chest she has findings of ground-glass changes and bilateral infiltrates.
She has a known history of ocular sarcoid but so far there has been no convincing evidence of systolic sarcoidosis.
Her PET scan was non-diagnostic.
Rita had a DSE performed in December 2022, which has been reported as normal with no evidence of inducible ischaemia.
This is reassuring in terms of possible underlying coronary artery disease as explanation of shortness of breath.
Rita reports that since she has stopped taking her eye drops, which was for glaucoma treatment, her symptoms are quite improved.
On examinations today, her blood pressure was 115/66mmHg, and heart sounds were dual with no murmur.
Her chest examination was clear.

At this stage, I have reassured her that her symptoms are likely not to be cardiac in nature, given her reassuring cardiac MRI, resting echocardiogram and a reassuring dobutamine stress echocardiogram.
She is due to see the Respiratory Physician next month, the outcome of which will be important.
I have booked her for a review in the Cardiology Clinic  in 12 months and if by that time, there are no new cardiac concerns, we will likely discharge her from the Cardiology Clinic.
Please continue with your ongoing care and feel free to contact us if you have any concerns in the interim.

															- Target weight 80-90kg

															- Prednisone 25-->50mg daily; 6 months of tapering steroid treatment,

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Illaeus via telephone today.
He had requested a phone review himself, therefore there was no ECG performed today.
His echocardiogram in September shows recovery of his LV function but the LV remains dilated.
His ejection fraction is 54%.
He reports no palpitations, his breathing is normal now and he feels more energised.
Today he has requested to go through each one of his tablets and explain the rationale, as he is worried that he might get toxicity with his bad experience from Amiodarone.
I have reassured him that Sotalol does not cause thyroid toxicity, but it is an antiarrhythmic agent.
We have discussed that the use of this is to keep him in normal rhythm.
With the Atorvastatin, he needs a repeat LDL, and you can adjust the dose accordingly.
He has made a huge effort in losing a lot of weight which is excellent.
This will also help him remain in sinus rhythm for a longer time.
It would be nice to see him in person at the next opportunity and to repeat an ECG, as such I have offered him an in-person review in about 12 months.
He is to continue taking all his tablets.
