														Dear Dr Rafiei

														

														

														RE:	JOSEPH CORLETT		DOB:	23/03/1961		UR:	180494

																					

														

														

														Issues:
# Mechanical aortic valve and ascending aorta replacement (2003)
   - performed by Dr. Peter Tesar in the Prince Charles Hospital.

- for TTE and review every 3-5 years
   - requires antibiotic prophylaxis for dental work and low threshold for antibiotics for 

														     wounds
# Staph aureus (MSSA) bacteraemia (September 2021)
   - complicated by post-infectious GN
   - no impact on aortic valve function - did not require re-do surgery
   - discharged from ID
# T2DM
# Atrial flutter
   - ablation 2016 (Dr. Kaye)
# Amiodarone induced thyroiditis
# OA in knees
# Anxiety/depression
# Clot in right eye on warfarin (~50 years old)
   - advised to take aspirin/warfarin concurrently
   - localised vision loss - stable

Medications:
warfarin, frusemide 200mg mane, verapamil SR 240mg daily, propranolol 40mg BD (prefers to stay on this rather than trial metoprolol at present), prazosin 1mg BD, metformin XR 2000mg nocte, gliclazide 60mg MR mane, atorvastatin 40mg nocte, sertraline 50mg mane, aspirin 100mg daily

														

														I had the pleasure of reviewing Joseph Corlett in our Cardiology Outpatient Clinic today.
He is known to this clinic for monitoring of his mechanical aortic valve and ascending aortic replacement that was performed in 2003.
The last time that he was seen in this clinic was approximately 2 years ago.

Since then, Joseph has had a tumultuous time with staph aureus bacteraemia complicated by post infectious glomerulonephritis  Fortunately, his mechanical aortic valve and ascending aortic replacement were not involved, and redo surgery was not required.
He has since completed his antibiotic course and has been discharged from Infectious Diseases with no subsequent concerning symptoms of ongoing infection.
Joseph has had no palpitations in recent weeks, especially after discontinuing his antibiotic and Esomeprazole.
Interestingly, he also reports noticing palpitations with the use of Telmisartan.
From a social perspective, Joseph works as a mobile breakdown mechanic for large construction equipment such as bulldozer and diggers.
He does not drink alcohol, or smoke, or use recreational drugs.
His only vice, he tells me, is chocolate.
On examination today, Joseph appeared well.
His heart rate was 64bpm and regular, corresponding with an ECG in sinus rhythm.
His blood pressure was 135/75mmHg and his examination was overall unremarkable.
I noticed that, perhaps as a result of his subjective symptoms of palpitations with Amlodipine, Telmisartan and other medications, he has been started on a large dose of Frusemide at 200mg mane.
This is in addition to his Verapamil slow release at 240mg daily, and Propranolol 40mg twice daily, and Prazosin 1mg twice daily.
From a prognostic perspective, it would be preferential for Joseph to have RAAS inhibition via either ACE inhibitor or ARB.
Therefore,  have taken the liberty of prescribing Joseph a small dose of Perindopril 2.5mg nocte.

Should this be effective in decreasing his blood pressure, I would suggest that his Frusemide dose be gradually decreased, while increasing his Perindopril dose to the maximum tolerated dose clinically and as allowed by biochemical parameters on regular testing.
I would recommend against using both dihydropyridine and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers concurrently.
The use of Frusemide may not be required as Joseph does not have any fluid retention and has a normal cardiac function.
However, I will leave the titration of his antihypertensive therapy in your capable hands to be guided by his upcoming pathology panel that you have already arranged.
With respect to his diabetes control, I would suggest considering the addition of Empagliflozin or Dapagliflozin to his usual Metformin, should his HbA1c increase above 7.0%.
This would be beneficial for his diabetic control as well as his cardiac and renal outcome long-term.
Lastly, I have reiterated the importance of addressing any skin wounds for other potential vectors for infection as early as possible to prevent a recurrence of systolic infection.
Joseph is very clear on this requirement and will be diligent in ensuring this.
I will arrange to review Joseph again in approximately 24 months with a repeat transthoracic echocardiogram.
Thank you for your ongoing care of Mr Corlett.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr Jackson,





RE:	PETER CORNISH		DOB:	6/09/1952		UR:	888693

							



														Peter returned to heart failure titration clinic today.
He continues to feel quite weak and unable to manage much of his activities of daily living related to ongoing breathlessness.
He complains of breathlessness at rest, it is definitely worse on exertion and is most likely related to his COPD.
Some days are worse than others.
He currently has a productive cough; however he has not had a recent illness/fevers.
Unfortunately, he continues to smoke 15-20 roll your own cigarettes per day.
He has no intention of quitting as he feels it is too difficult.
I did have a brief discussion today about strategies.
He told me that he has tried everything, and it has not been helpful.
He continues to sleep elevated on about 6 pillows.

Medications

														Vit D 50mcg BD, Actonel weekly on Monday, Prednisone self-decreased 17.5mg mane, Aspirin 100mg nocte, Clopidogrel 75mg mane, Bisoprolol 2.5mg mane (increased to 3.75mg mane), Ramipril 1.25mg BD, Rosuvastatin 40mg mane, Ezetimibe 10mg mane, Pantoprazole 20mg nocte, Trelegy puffer mane, Atrovent II puffs QID (I believe that Peter is using this more frequently up to 8 x day), GTN PRN.
He has ceased all of his pain medication as he feels that the pain is well managed.
Peter states that he tolerated the increase in Bisoprolol from when I saw him last.
On examination his blood pressure was 100/70mmHg sitting and 95/70mmHg standing, heart rate 84bpm and regular.
There was no evidence of oedema.
Today I have increased the Bisoprolol to 3.75mg mane.
I will see him back in this clinic in four weeks.
I have asked him to see you for an assessment of his COPD and perhaps additional therapy.
I understand that he is known to the respiratory team at the Mater, I wonder if you would consider a referral back to them.

Yours sincerely, 





Robyn Peters

Nurse Practitioner Heart Failure

Princess Alexandra Hospital Heart Failure Service

Dear Dr Goodwill,





														RE:	CESARE CORRADO		DOB:	06/08/1934		UR:	253597

																					

														

														Diagnosis:

														Ischemic heart disease

														inferolateral STEMI

														PCI to RCA 18.01.2021 with drug eluding stents 

														PCI to LAD 29.01.2021 (drug eluding stent)

														Clouded OM3 (small vessel medical management)

														Hypertension

														

														Medications:

														Isosorbide Mononitrate 120mg mane, Pantoprazole 40mg nocte, Aspirin 100mg once a day, Atenolol 25mg mane, Atorvastatin 40mg nocte,  Telmisartan/HCT 40/12.5mg.
Cesare came in for review today.
It has been over a year since I have seen him and for the most part, he has been well in that time.
He did have some chest pains several days, though it followed some heavy work around his house.
It resolved with no intervention.
He has returned to walking and exercise with no recurrent symptoms.
On examination today his heart rate was 70bpm and regular.
His heart sounds were dual, and his chest was clear to auscultation.
His ECG confirmed sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischaemia.
Cesare’s most recent episode of chest pains seems atypical and was not exertional.
From his history it seems musculoskeletal in origin.
I will continue with secondary prevention unchanged and plan to review him progress in 12 months.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Greg,





RE:	LORETO CORTEZ		DOB:	11/04/1937		UR:	2234931

							





														Cardiovascular Diagnoses:

														Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR in SAVR) degeneration of previous surgical aortic valve replacement.

Previous 25mm mitroflow at the Townsville Hospital with subsequent evolution severe regurgitant degeneration with resultant left ventricular dilatation, symptomatic deterioration and functional mitral regurgitation.

TAVR with Abbott Portico 25 mm bioprosthesis at Princess Alexandra Hospital on 25 November 2022

														Ischaemic heart disease.
CABG at time of SAVR in 2009 at Townsville Hospital.
Previous abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.

Cardiovascular Risk Factors:

														Hypertension.
Dyslipidaemia.

Other Conditions:

														Myelodysplastic syndrome with multilineage dysplasia 

														Osteoporosis.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Previous gout.

Medications:

														Apixaban 5mg twice daily, Bisoprolol 2.5mg daily, Frusemide 40mg daily, Irbesartan 300mg daily, Rosuvastatin 10mg daily, Ezetimibe 10mg daily, Allopurinol 300mg daily, Denosumab as directed.
I reviewed Loreto Cortez today via telehealth link.
Following his TAVR procedure, he did have some issues with thrombocytopaenia.
He had a repeat haematology and bone marrow assessment.
His platelet count seems to have recovered.
He has had no recurrence of cardiac decompensation or cardiac failure.
No angina.
No significant dyspnoea.
(NYHA class I – II).
His most recent platelet count had improved.
Given the combination of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and the bioprosthetic aortic valve, I have asked Loreto to recommence his Apixaban today.
I have also asked Loreto to have his GP recheck his full blood count / platelet count in 2 to 4 weeks.

RE:	LORETO CORTEZ		DOB:	11/04/1937		UR:	2234931

														

														Plan and Recommendations:

														Recommence DOAC (Apixaban) 5mg twice daily.
Monitoring of ELFT and FBC in 2 to 4 weeks and then every 12 weeks via LMO.
Antibiotic prophylaxis for any invasive procedures including dental procedures as a lifelong recommendation.
Cardiology follow up with Dr Greg Starmer at Cairns Base Hospital.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr McDonald,





RE:	CAMERON COSGROVE	DOB:	08/02/1986	UR:	8110205

							



														

														Thank you so much for your kind referral for Cameron who I saw today 11.1.2023.
He is a 36-year-old gentleman who works for a Shoe and Watch Repairer.
He had paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on 08.09.2022, whilst moving house.
He had multiple energy drinks and was under a lot of stress.
He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation confirmed on ECG.
He underwent a cardioversion is September 2022 at the PA Hospital.
He was initially on oral anticoagulation.
He is medicated on Sotalol 80mg orally BD.
ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm and normal QTc.
He is a non-smoker.
He does not imbibe alcohol and does not partake of caffeine.
He has a family history of atrial fibrillation with his father.
He had an echocardiogram performed in September 2022.
He has a normal left ventricular size and systolic function with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 45% by visual estimation.
Normal right ventricular size and systolic function.
He has normal thyroid function and normal urea and electrolytes.
We had a preliminary discussion regarding pulmonary vein ablation.
There is a 70% chance of improvement with the ablation, 25% of patient might require repeat procedure to achieve this.
It takes 3 months before the treatment takes effect.
There is a 2 to 5% risk of complication, including 2% risk of stroke, cardiac tamponade, 1 in 1000 risk death and 5% risk of venous access complication that may require surgery to fix.
He is happy to proceed should this be required.
I have organised to review in 12 months.
Ideally, he should lose weight, he is currently 135 kilograms, he should be approximately 100 kilograms and he will endeavour to achieve this.
If he forgets his Sotalol he does get palpitations.
I think if he gets further episodes, we should proceed to pulmonary vein ablation.
many thanks for your ongoing care of this patient.
If there are any problems, please do not hesitate to get in touch with me.

Yours sincerely, 

														

														Electronically signed 19.01.23

														A/Prof Paul Gould

														Consultant Cardiologist
